story:
September 24, 2014

Dear Ones,

Our very precious friend, teacher, mentor and Beloved Art Matriarch is in the "in between worlds" right now. After a very difficult bypass surgery she hasn't returned to us and we are shock as well as staying in wonder at her process. As we write this we have been sitting vigil by her bedside for over ten days and it has been 6 days since surgery - wondering when and if, she will awake. We are in profoundly deep sorrow as the chances are very slim.  Everyone is one of a kind but Sue is one in a million. As vast as the cosmos, she so often paints. We were all so certain she would come through, as she was so excited to continue in her vision, her love of teaching, and to continue the legacy of her land as a sanctuary for women.

Sue Hoya Sellars has a vision: To gather and guide others to commit art. She wanted us to experience a connection to ourselves, the land - to learn how to see - and to heal through intentional creating as anyone who has worked with her will understand and remember. She believed so strongly in the power of art to heal and as the way to connect with our consciousness that she has been working on this her entire life. We are so blessed to have a woman like this in our life a true mentor to pass on her teachings. We will continue to learn from both the legacy of her land - and the teachings from her notebooks.

How about a Barn raising instead of fundraising?

At first our community thought of a fundraiser to help during this difficult time, as there isn't an 'estate plan' to cover the expanse of expenses that happens when someone is in this kind of life transition. But she doesn't want to be a 'cause' and this isn't a traditional fundraiser. The most important thing for her life and legacy was and is to secure her land: Terra Sophia:  20 Acres of pristine land in the beautiful Anderson Valley. So we went with a Barn Raising. So much more Sue. And so much closer to her plans to have an Art Barn on her property.

We have some short term goals based on where we are on the journey at this time, which is to cover her immediate expenses. And we have our eye on her larger vision - yes, a barn raising is planned.... has been planned... and this vision helps us as a community focus on her and her wishes for her land. She was very clear with her desires for her property. She has been working with students there for over twenty years and she longed to continue that into her future.

So we, the community, would be most grateful for your participation and support during this time - and for you to keep the eye on the larger vision with us, while we focus on what is at hand right now. Which is our dear Sue. It is a curious journey to sit with someone on the edge of life and death and ponder what is really important to them...in some ways...it is the same thing. What they would want after their death is the same thing they would want if they were living.

We are working to secure the land. And so we shall.

IMMEDIATE GOAL

Our immediate short term goal is to cover Sue's mortgage and immediate medical costs for the next 4 months is estimated at around 30k - anything remaining will be used towards paying off the land.

PERK CHOICES

We know the perk choices aren't all fleshed out at this time - but we wanted to offer you something tangible in gratitude for your support and participation.

Buy Art

Another way to support Sue is to purchase prints from her Fine Art America site:
http://fineartamerica.com/profiles/sue-hoya-sel...

An INVITATION
This is an invitation to work with us on the legacy of the Terra Sophia Sanctuary. Let's create a dream together...it is Sue's dream, but it is also many of our dreams to have a sacred space to create that is beautiful and sustainable going into the future.

With great love and HOPE,

The Cosmic Cowgirls and The Red Thread Circle

Love Frequency – from the Master’s Notebook by Sue Hoya Sellars

The frequency of love is stepped down as it enters the dimension of time, space, matter. It connects with great care to the individual energetically at the POINT of the HEART.

This is why the heart develops in the fetus before the brain as it literally informs the life force of each person, preparing it to receive soul consciousness. When the soul moves through this channel forged by the heart it establishes a connection with Source Intelligence, Creator.


From heart to soul to spirit to…Creator.

Creativity of works of art: Love Frequency Transmission/Unconflicted/Timeless…

Time is a distortion of our connection with others and Goddess. Time intervenes….

September 26

By what feels like a miracle, our dear Sue Hoya was able to return home to her mountain Terra Sophia to transition. While her passing is imminent we are so very grateful that she was able to survive the trip home. She is surrounded by friends and family and prayer. Cosmic Cowgirls and their families have been working on Terra Sophia with the vision of the sanctuary and barn raising in the future.

September 27

Sue is seeming much much more peaceful since being removed from all the invasive life support measures. And yes, we were clear as her community that it was time, and it was in her Advanced Directives for healthcare to not be kept on life support if her chance of recovery or a meaningful life was very slim. Of course we hoped beyond hope that she would still wake up from her 'coma' state, but she hasn't.

The community is building her a 'spaceship' for the journey home of her physical body although we know her spirit is soaring in the stars.

September 29

Our dear Art Matriarch has journeyed on. More details to be shared as we are able.

story:
Our Story

At Burning Man 2013, Shane Evans had a life changing experience that inspired him to push his artistic and technical skills to the next level. He decided to build a giant robot with fire effects and beautiful lighting that people could control. In October 2013, Shane began building the Robot. Over the course of 6 months a crew of volunteers coalesced around his vision to bring the Robot to life. Every person brought their skills to the project and learned more, the support continued and a community formed. We Are The Robots. In June 2014 the Robot appeared at a festival of 2,000 people in Colorado to much fanfare. The Robot crew now wants to help Shane see his vision through, by bringing it to Burning Man 2014 to drive across the earth. This is why we need your support.

What We Need and Why

This campaign is to raise $8,500 but in an ideal world we would raise $10,000.

First priority: $3,000 for drive, steering, brakes and mounting systems to make the base a mobile platform.

The existing base of the Robot does not accommodate these things, we need to build it all. Estimates put that cost around $2,000. Repairs to the skin, igniters, and lighting effects are also minor but necessary. These repairs will be about $1,000 and will be protected in transport by the box truck.

Second priority: $7,000 for a 16' box truck and gas to drive a 2,000 lb Robot 2,000 miles.

See the photos in our gallery for the transportation we have now. You'll see why we need something new.

Some parts of the robot need to be protected during transport so a box truck is imperative. We've found a truck we want for $5,000. A box truck will also allow the crew to transport essential tools, as well as batteries, compressors, and propane tanks for Robot performances. Hauling the truck over mountain passes will require around $2,000 in gas.

The Impact You Will Make

No matter how much we raise, your support will help a proven artist propel his career to the next level. Burning Man is a festival of 73,000 people where the biggest and most complex experiential art exists. By bringing the Robot to Burning Man, Shane will have an opportunity to connect with like-minded artists and funders who could support his work in the future.

The Robot is made from 90% recycled airplane parts. Reusing existing materials in a new way is a key concept in all of Shane's art. At a time when consumption is rising and disposable goods are the way of life, the Robot communicates a very powerful alternate idea. A large venue like Burning Man will help to spread the word that there is value in the things that people discard. Using existing materials also helps to keep costs down.

The Robot crew are all volunteers. We helped build it because we wanted to create something great to share with the world. The power of participation is demonstrated through the formation of the community that has supported the Robot. We want to take it to Burning Man to encourage wider participation in it's existence and show others that big things are possible.

Building the Robot was a dream that was achieved by a leader, his crew and the support of a community. Installing and operating the Robot for the first time at a mountain festival in front of 2,000 people was a risk that paid off in huge ways. We made on-site repairs to the small glitches we encountered and dealt with very un-level ground successfully. All challenges were overcome. The Robot and it's team are proven. Now we want to do more.


The "What If?"...

If we don't raise our ideal goal of $10,000 then we will prioritize funds this way.

1. Build the mobile platform upgrades because Shane's vision is for the Robot to move freely across the ground. Funds will go to this task first and foremost.

2. Transportation and gas. It is a huge challenge to find 4+ trucks, drivers and gas (think of the waste!) to haul the Robot and all of it's components 2,000 miles for a 7 day festival. Our crew has already poured their hearts, souls and money into this project and we would love to pay for their gas if the drive happens in multiple trucks. A box truck would be ideal because it would solve the problem of multiple trucks and gas for each one.

Other Ways You Can Support Us

  • Share our story with artists, fabricators, engineers, electricians, fire performers, and your friends and family!
  • Do you live in Colorado and have, or know someone who has a 23' box truck for sale?
  • Do you have a gas card to gift to the Robot?
  • Are you a trucker who is willing to haul the Robot 2,000 miles for us?
  • Do you cook or own a restaurant and love to feed crews of people building a giant Robot?
  • Do you own a bar or liquor store and want to donate beer to motivate the crew?

story:
Help support two amazing groups of artists and two #NewPlays!!


2 stories about young people struggling to live out 2 intensely different fantasies only to realize that reality is different than what they imagined.

1) Grey Room is presenting "Workplace Professional", a new play by the promising emerging playwright, Josh Brown. Workplace Professional is a dark comedy about interns locked in a dog-eat-dog struggle for a staff job at Politipress: a prestigious news website. It explores themes of integrity, professionalism, and the extremes to which people will go to get what they want when faced with impossible odds.


Grey Room presents:
 Workplace Professional
 A new comedy by Josh Brown
Directed by Jake Beck
Produced by Mike Wesolowski, Jenna Lloyd, & Tom Blake.
Cast:
Mike Puckett
Shelby Leshine
Sarah Harper
Ben Schrager


Dates:
Thurs May 29 8pm
Fri May 30 8pm
Sat May 31 2pm
Sat May 31 8pm
Sun June 1 8pm
Tues June 3 8pm
Wed June 4 8pm
Thurs June 5 8pm
Fri June 6 8pm
Sat June 7 2pm
Sat June 7 8pm


2) The Shaker Secessionists are presenting a workshop production of “Anarcadia,” a devised play exploring the heady idealism involved in the creation of their own personal fantasies. Straddling the line between an activist-utopia-planning meeting and a bacchanalian fantasia, the play takes the audience on a journey with the performers through their anarchic and desperate attempts to idealize their place in the world.


 The Shaker Secessionists present:
 A workshop production of
Anarcadia (A Pastoral)
 Directed by JP Faianza
Produced by Tom Blake
Created by the Company
Featuring
Braulio Cruz
Teri Madonna
Francisco Huergo
Design by
Joel Grossman
May 24/25 @ 8pm
133rd St. Art Center, 
Harlem
http://133artscenter.com/visit/

story:
I have an amazing opportunity this summer and with your financial help I will be able to participate this summer with the Creative Current Summer Art Residency. Let me share with you a little of what this summer will consist of and what I intend on doing during my three week stay. My art work from an artistic and scholarly practice is based on African, Latin and Asian cultures, the history of textiles and the role fashion plays from a contemporary aspect in reference to image and identity.

The Creative Current Summer Art Residency will be based on a conceptual show inspired from the cultural influences specific to Panama, the project will be achieved by mixing various art mediums to blend contemporary art with cultural textiles. This project is a collaborative initiative for children and adults to reflect on their own personal stories of Portobelo, Panama through art and fashion that will eventually become canvas to be displayed for the "Walking Art" exhibition. The exchange with the people of Portobelo is an opportunity to learn more about Panama and the resourcefulness and creativity of the local community

What sets these fashionable creations apart is that the clothing serves as a canvas and art medium to both be worn and framed in a traditional gallery setting. The goal of the "Walking Art" exhibition is to install the fashionable canvases in a pop-up gallery to illustrate the multiple function of textile, fashion and cultural art.

I currently have several expenses regarding my art career in addition to the expenses associated with the residency. All of the funding you donate will go towards travel to Panama, room and board, meals, art supplies, assistants, installation, travel within the country, and other miscellaneous expenses.

I believe the voice of people in the community you are working with should be present in your art work. For the past year I have been collaborating with organizations from New York to Los Angeles whose focus is community and cultural democracy. These cultural exchanges in Panama can possibly lead to annual events held by artists within the community.

This residency is essential to enriching my work and sets a different
range of challenges that will broaden my way of thinking. It is my belief the
residency at Portobelo will begin a lifelong relationship with the country of
Panama.

 

Please spread the word by sharing the link

Thank you for all of your support.

story: Miss Teen Sullivan County International 2012, Miss Teen Hudson Valley International 2013 and our very own, Miss Teen New York International 2014 Marina Lopez-Braddock is currently advocating for teens by promoting, TADD (Teens Against Distracted Driving) amongst other problems facing our teens in society, today. She is passionate about her family, friends, school and all else. Miss Teen New York International 2014; Marina Lopez-Braddock will be making appearances and promoting her platform; TADD throughout the Empire State. We are humbly asking ALL to show their support while Marina embarks on this wonderful journey spreading the word about destructive decisions teens are faced with. Marina is a genuine soul looking out for the best interests of her family, friends and all others. As Miss Teen New York International, Marina will be representing the Empire State at the International Pageant in Jacksonville, Florida. Please help us make this possible for Marina. Thank you all in advance for your continued support.

story:
The Yoknapatawpha Arts Council serves the entire community. Our staff, board members, volunteers and partners work to provide new experiences for your family through the arts. Your ongoing support has made it possible for talented artists to enrich our community, to provide opportunities for everyone to be part of the creative process, and to launch new programs that will continue to define us as an arts community.

Your membership is key to our ability to plan a full year of programming. A membership in the arts council is an investment in our community. Membership donations provide the resources for the Arts Council to seed educational programs, to support community projects such as the Art Truck, which provides free art classes throughout our county, and offer free events such as the Oxford Art Crawl. 

I invite you to renew your membership and join us at our annual membership event on May 16th at Avent Park at 6 p.m.

In just the past few years, with the support you provide, over $500,000 of improvements have been completed on the building including new theater seats, lighting and sound equipment,  backstage, and the sculpture garden. These enhancements have made it possible to present original works by performers, to provide a venue for screening independent films, to host classes for children and adult programs, and to attract national tours to our community. The Arts Council’s long range plans will transform the remainder of the building.

All that we offer the community is because of your support. I ask you to please renew your membership today!

story:
Lil gnomies was an idea that  the lil gnomies thought up to help bridge the gap between humans and lil gnomies. This campaign is very important to the lil gnomies to help get the word out about lil gnomies figurines and to better educate humans on lil gnomies.  Lil gnomies are very positive karma filled gnomies that look out for animals, plants and humans. They pay it forward and encourage you to pay it forward everyday.  This campaign is very important to the other founders and myself because lil gnomies have always looked out for us and now we need to look out for them.


By pledging money to this campaign you can help spread joy and happiness all over the world, one lil gnomie at a time.  


The funds that we raise will go towards production of the lil gnomies, prototype and mold costs.  

Check out our perks...there are some really cool things you can get for helping the lil gnomies get this going.  If we do not reach our goal, the money raised will still go to production.  This project is awesome on so many levels.  For one, lil gnomies can bring joy and happiness in a small and inexpensive way.  These will sell for around $1 and bring joy and happiness to everyone from 4 years to 400 years (some gnomies live to be 500 years old). Our main hurdle will be getting the word out.  We plan to overcome this by building a large social media network and by going to trade shows to help build the fan base organically. 

We are going to launch September 25-29 at Alamo City Comic Con.  

If you can not pledge, please forward this to your friends, like us on Facebook and look for the lil gnomies this fall!  

Ooh Callooh!!!

story:
While I love and embrace the digital age, there seems to be something less romantic about gazing at an iphone to see pictures and videos. With more than 800 billions images and videos created every year. Wouldn’t it be nice to create art from some of them – art that you can physically engage with and form a connection to. 

Invented in 1833 the zoetrope was kind of like a 19th century gif viewer.  Strips of images were placed in a cylinder which was then spun. When viewed through the slits in the sides, the images began to animate. 

I wanted to make the zoe modern while retaining and enhancing its interactive quality. It was important to me that it looks cool just sitting there, so I put the art on the outside and lit the zoëtrope from within. 

A modern take on an old classic. Born in 1833. Reborn 2014. Enter the zoëtrope.

         

A beautiful wood base with custom laser cut gears and custom printed shades. Lit by electricity and animated by hand.

Yes, you can turn your family videos into art. Immortalize a wedding dance, your babies first steps,  grandma blowing a kiss, the winning shot, an amazing swing, a kick, a dive, even a stupid pet trick.  Create a one of a kind cinema inspired animated zoëtrope. Or, since the art is changeable create many.

                                    


Funds will help to cover production costs and enable me to put the finish touches to the design, the mechanisms, the electronics and the materials needed to bring my zoëtropes to life/light.



A thank you page will forever be on my website. And a printed thank you will be included with every zoëtrope ever shipped that says:

                         “this zoëtrope exists, thanks to these fine people” 


Double your animation pleasure with this pocket size movie. This one is a zoëtrope secuence of a dog running and jumping. And who doesn’t like dogs running and jumping?  (fyi: the gif above is triple the animation, a gif of a flipbook of a zoëtrope) 

Also, the never ending thank you. Thank you.



Wear a zoëtrope with pride. This one's banannamated (sorry). Unfourtunatly, no matter how fast you spin, this t-shirt will not actually animate. But you will also get the never ending thank you. Thank you.



An old style zoëtrope (with a modern design) includes 4 strips ready to be spun. And of course the never ending thank you. Thank you.



The flipbook, the t-shirt, and the old style zoëtrope, with the 4 strips, and yes, the "never ending thank you"



A zoëtrope light with one cylinder ‘o animation. Limited edition art of your choice.

This is a special Indiegogo price. The zoëtrope is numbered and signed by the artist. And of course, the "never ending thank you" is included.



A geared zoëtrope light with a cylinder ‘o animation based on video that you supply.

This is a special Indiegogo price. The zoëtrope is numbered and signed by the artist.   And of course, the "never ending thank you" is included.


A geared zoëtrope with a cylinder ‘o animation based on video that I will come and shoot anywhere in the NY tristate area. For further distances, transportation, etc would be extra. 

This is a special Indiegogo price. The zoëtrope is numbered and signed by the artist.   And of course, the "never ending thank you" is included.


* Perks include free delivery to the contiguous 48 states. Hawaiian, Alaskan and international backers are required to pay the cost of shipping and will also be responsible for taxes, duties, and customs fees for their orders (minus a $10 dollar credit).

story:
Short Summary

The Canadian Frame(lines) project seeks to foster learning and discussion around the ideas of Canadian cultural identity through community engagement and film craft workshops. This project has given Canadians across the country a platform to share, in their own words and images, the stories that define themselves and our nation. We’ve successfully engaged diverse demographics: from the young to the old, Canadian-born people, indigenous people, immigrants, and anglo- and francophones. We have always sought to maintain a bias-free environment where all opinions and views are incorporated into a larger and more comprehensive total view of the country’s ideas.

So far, we have worked in 9 seperate communities: Pender Harbour, British Columbia; Cremona, Alberta; Gravelbourg, Saskatchewan; St. Stephen, New Brunswick; Tignish, Prince Edward Island; Tyendinaga Mohawk Territory; Tobermory, Ontario;  Baie Verte, Newfoundland and Seaforth, Nova Scotia. We will be working with 3 more communities before the end of the year, including Stanbridge East, Quebec; Carman, Manitoba; and one additional First Nations community in British Columbia.

The Impact

Here's what people have said about how the Canadian Frame(lines) project has affected their communities:

“…I  was moved by the impact Canadian Framelines left on our little community and would welcome them back again to carry on from where they left off. They really did bring our small community together for the month and left behind some friendships and bonding that would not have taken place otherwise. Close to 100 residents attended the premier viewing of the 10 locally produced films. It was a very emotional experience for me personally to see the people who would not normally participate get as involved as they did and mix with the younger generation. Since they have left community members are still talking about the experience and what else we could be doing to let the rest of Canada know who we are…” – Gail C.

Alexandra in Cremona, Alberta

“…This month long project brought together participants from both the Village and the county.  The participants included students from the village school, local business owners, farmers, retirees, amongst others.  From each unique perspective we all gained insights into each other’s diverse realities – and perhaps developed an appreciation for those realities.  From my perspective this is a clear example of using arts as a tool of social change…” – Karel B.

Processing film with a participant in our onboard darkroom.

“…In early January of this year, they pulled their bus into town and eagerly got to work. In the end, we had eight people step forward to participate each bringing a different view point. Our eight brave filmmakers brought a variety of perspectives including volunteerism, youth, marine history, and heritage… There was a definite sense of pride and accomplishment from those involved including their friends and family who attended the final screening event…” – Francine L.

Ryder teaching high school students in Alberta about documentary camerawork.

"Caulfield and White teach complete strangers how to shoot and hand-process Super 8 film, asking people to record their impressions of "home." An old medium that is new to the people learning to use it, Super 8 helps people to experience the everyday and image-making differently." – Jennifer VanderBurgh, Associate Professor of Film and Media Studies, Saint Mary's University


Sharing The Films With A Wider Audience

Upon our return to Vancouver, the short films made by people across the country will be exhibited in a gallery setting. All of the films from a given community will be grouped and displayed together on their own dedicated projector. Visitors will be able to walk through the twelve total projections and as such will experience a tour of Canada through the images produced by individuals from all across the country. Some collected artifacts, expository material, and soundscapes will augment the exhibition. The first staging of this show will be held in Vancouver, BC but we hope to be able to set it up in several additional Canadian sites and elsewhere! However, in order to do this, we'll need some help from you.

What We Need

Canadian Frame(lines) has been run entirely off of our own personal savings and two fundraisers that we held last year–we do not operate under the auspices of any governmental or institutional grants. In order to finish the project and share these films with the world, we need to raise a bit more money.

Here is a breakdown of how we will spend the required funds:

$178 Preparation of films for digitization

$3,550 $1/ft of film Digitization of Films

$60 Participant DVD Production

$150 Participant DVD Shipping

$4,800 = $400 x 12 – 12 mini projectors

$420 = $35 x 12 – 12 high capacity (32gb) sd cards

(We are buying the 12 projectors & SD cards because it is actually more cost effective than renting the same projectors and cards.) 

$150 Printing of gallery materials

$800 Perks

Sub-Total =    $10,108

Indiegogo Fees (we’re assuming we’re reaching our goal!)

+ $405 = 4% Indiegogo’s cut

+ $304 = 3% Credit Card Processing Fees

+ $25 ‘Wire Fee’ for being located outside the U.S.A.

Grand Total = $10,842

What You Get

In addition to the wonderful feeling of generosity and benevolence that come from knowing that you supported the education and engagement of people with whom you share this planet and a project that has taken a 100% independent survey of Canadian culture in the 21st Century, you will also be able to choose from our selection of perks! From filmmaking instruction to red carpet galas, there's something for everyone so be sure to peruse the list on the right side of this page.

Come Home is a feature-length documentary film that we are currently making that parallels the Canadian Frame(lines) project and exhibition. Composed primarily of footage taken during Come Home Year 2013 in the small town of Baie Verte, Newfoundland, Come Home examines what home and place identity mean to people, especially as our society becomes increasingly mobile and worldly. Though separate and distinct from Canadian Frame(lines), Come Home addresses the same basic theme: how does where we're from make us who we are? Hopefully you'll see them both! For more information on Come Home, visit our website: CaulfieldWhite.com/ComeHome.


Other Ways You Can Help

Every donation, every dollar, helps. That being said, we know not everyone can make a donation at this time. Another wonderful way to help us out is by spreading the word: Indiegogo has many ways to let you share the project on your personal Facebook and Twitter accounts, or for a more personal approach, send a quick email to any contacts you think would appreciate this project. You can also share the videos from our Youtube channel to help raise awareness about our project.

Thanks for viewing! We look forward to bringing you more content as the campaign continues.

story:
As Night Ascends the Wolves Awake, Oil on canvas 44 x 79 in




The Story:



All my life I have been involved with art.  I’d say it’s more love than work.  When I was really young I spontaneously began to draw, and from then on I never stopped creating.  

 

Through the years I grew and developed into an artist.  My mother immersed my brother and I with as many galleries, museums, and overall cultural experiences as possible early in our lives.  This left a lasting mark in my life.  I trained in various art mediums through high school.  After graduating, I set out to develop a really strong portfolio in order to apply and be accepted to some of the major art schools in the nation.  Taking classes part time at a local university, I realized that if I was going to accomplish my degree I would need some financial support.  So I stopped school and started my own industrial pallet recycling company with my brother.  

 

We started it with nothing and eventually built it up to where I was able to return to school full-time with some financial support, get a 4.0 GPA with all my humanities and science courses done, and transfer to a major art institution.  I am now studying Fine Art in Seattle, and I am truly blessed.  

 

For years now I have explored different avenues of the painting process, searching for my own unique method to then launch my career into the art world.  After hundreds of paintings and years of experimentation I have found two specific processes that I now want to develop into a master collection of 30-50 paintings.  In doing this I will have a body of work that I can then present to major galleries and collectors to then be represented and grow into a career in the international art world.  I think that with my background in business, and my passion in art, I can be very successful in this endeavor.  I am very driven, and above all else I have had this specific vision that I know can come to fruition with the right amount of hard work and persistence.  

 

So the reason I am launching this indiegogo crowd funding campaign is so that I can have the funds to accomplish this collection of paintings.  Between living cost, tuition, and everything in my life, I won’t have the financial ability to do this immediately.  Even though I am completely ready, trained, and have the goal, I still have this one limitation that I know we as a collective group can overcome.  Materials are just crazy expensive in painting.  So with your help, and everybody pitching in little by little, we can pull together the funds to complete this 2013 collection of paintings. Thanks so much for your support.








                                    The Lion Lives,  Oil on canvas 60 x 60 inches




Bio:

 

I am an interdisciplinary multimedia artist focusing in video/film, painting, photography, printmaking, sculpture, digital work, and drawing.  Between sculpture, photography, digital, I have many works and methods in progress.  I recently was named assistant director on a short film here in Seattle, as well as producing and directing my own shorts.  I approach my work crossing many mediums to derive a collective whole.  Right now, I want to create a 2013 collection of paintings.  For years now I’ve been on the hunt for a new and experimental method of painting, and after completing over a hundred or so works in that investigation, I found it.  

 

It has been my vision to execute 30-50 paintings all in large scale.  The reason for the size of the images to be so grand is so the viewer can be encompassed by these somewhat other worlds that are created.  Its is my goal to execute at least 30 so that I can have a large body of work to then be able to present to galleries, collectors, and agencies in order to gain representation, launching my career in the international art world.  In the act of being a successful artist, you have to have a concise method and a deliberate art practice to go forth from.  So in developing this method I have found that definitive style that can then be explored in a series of 30 - 50 paintings.  This is so exciting for me because I am finally ready to step out into the art world with strong, streamlined work that I am passionate about.




  

                                          Lunar Eclipse, Oil on panel 48 x 60 in




Logistics:

 

This brings us to the point of why we're here today.  Painting is expensive, bottom line.  It’s gonna take a lot to pull this off, but I feel it can happen.  On top of applying for grant opportunities, I’m launching this indiegogo to fund this campaign.  In order to do this I need very specific materials and that can get pricey.  Oil paint is a very refined product with some smaller tubes starting at ten dollars going up to a hundred or more. The thing is with my process I use a lot of paint, and tubes won’t cut it.  So I have to buy gallons of oil paint, costing around 75.00 a piece.  With a collection this big and dealing with larger scale, this is definitely a necessity.  So in order to have a full spectrum and to be able to develop the work to it’s full potential, I will need around 20-30 different colors in gallon form.  Not to worry.  It all can happen and it can be beautiful.  Other materials are going to include door skin paneling to make canvas supports, 2x2 wood to reinforce the panels, canvas to stretch over the panels so that the canvas won’t warp from the weight of the paint, at least 30 gallons of gesso to coat and seal the canvas from the oil paint, screws and wood glue to attach the wooden panel structures, staples for the canvas, 3 box fans for ventilation, one shop fan, chop saw, skill saw, 2 work tables.  I want to execute starting in July and working through the fall of this year.

 

Door skin panel               30 pieces x 30.00                  750.00

2x2 wood                       120 pieces x 10.00                 1200.00

Canvas 96 in. 11 oz        120 yards x 12.70                  1560.00

Oil Paint                         30 gallons x 75.00                 2250.00

Gesso                            30 gallons x 30.00                 900.00

 

Chop saw                                                                   200.00

Screws                                                                      100.00

2 work tables                                                              45.00

Skill saw                                                                    100.00

2 saw guides                                                              30.00

Wood glue                                                                  25.00

Ventamatic shop vac                                                  150.00

3 box fans                                                                  75.00

 

 

Total Supplies:                                                           7,385.00

 

Incidentals:                                                                115.00

 

Total:                                                                        7,500.00





                        

                                               Dark Star, Oil on canvas 82 x 34 in



How you can help:

 

So as you can see this is somewhat of a daunting task.  But with this method of crowd funding, as a team we can pull this together and make a dream come true.  I have been a practicing artist all my life, the difference now is that I am ready to emerge into the art world with a strong body of work.  And through your help, this can happen. You have that opportunity through this campaign, to be apart of history, and help an artist succeed in doing great work.  Thank you so much for your support.  Thank you so much for being you.




                                       

                                                   Krystal Kastle, Oil 24 x 78.5 in





                                       

                       As Night Ascends Upon The Streets Of L.A., Oil on wood 24 x 78.5 in

 




                                

                             The Skies Were Open Bare, Oil on canvas/panel 30 x 78.5 in



The tiers for donation:

 

The way indiegogo and crowdfunding sites like this work is through donations of many people, large (and small) task can be accomplished.  In the donation list of reciprocated gratitude on the right, I have included prints of the new collection of paintings to be a gift to you throughout the different tier levels.  I have deliberately withheld selling any of my work so when I did decide to enter the art market, it would be on my terms and I could dictate how the work would be shown, sold, and subsequently handled.  There is no doubt in my mind that art is a business, and through that I never wanted my product to be watered down.  Instead I want it to be refined, rare, and sought after.  It is through this understanding that I am now going to enter the market, with a strong, grounded, body of work.  Thank you so much.

This is what it’s all about:

 

I just want to say thank you for the support.  Thank you to all my friends, my family, and everyone who’s ever been apart of my life.  I am so grateful for you, and this opportunity to be, what I’ve always wanted to be, an artist.  So with this, I will diligently work hard at achieving and producing great work.  For you and all those who have believed in me.  

 

                                                             Thank You.

                                             One of the best things in life is art.

                                                                 JMP
story_txt:
As Night Ascends the Wolves Awake, Oil on canvas 44 x 79 in

The Story:

All my life I have been involved with art.  I’d say it’s more love than work.  When I was really young I spontaneously began to draw, and from then on I never stopped creating.  
 
Through the years I grew and developed into an artist.  My mother immersed my brother and I with as many galleries, museums, and overall cultural experiences as possible early in our lives.  This left a lasting mark in my life.  I trained in various art mediums through high school.  After graduating, I set out to develop a really strong portfolio in order to apply and be accepted to some of the major art schools in the nation.  Taking classes part time at a local university, I realized that if I was going to accomplish my degree I would need some financial support.  So I stopped school and started my own industrial pallet recycling company with my brother.  
 
We started it with nothing and eventually built it up to where I was able to return to school full-time with some financial support, get a 4.0 GPA with all my humanities and science courses done, and transfer to a major art institution.  I am now studying Fine Art in Seattle, and I am truly blessed.  
 
For years now I have explored different avenues of the painting process, searching for my own unique method to then launch my career into the art world.  After hundreds of paintings and years of experimentation I have found two specific processes that I now want to develop into a master collection of 30-50 paintings.  In doing this I will have a body of work that I can then present to major galleries and collectors to then be represented and grow into a career in the international art world.  I think that with my background in business, and my passion in art, I can be very successful in this endeavor.  I am very driven, and above all else I have had this specific vision that I know can come to fruition with the right amount of hard work and persistence.  
 
So the reason I am launching this indiegogo crowd funding campaign is so that I can have the funds to accomplish this collection of paintings.  Between living cost, tuition, and everything in my life, I won’t have the financial ability to do this immediately.  Even though I am completely ready, trained, and have the goal, I still have this one limitation that I know we as a collective group can overcome.  Materials are just crazy expensive in painting.  So with your help, and everybody pitching in little by little, we can pull together the funds to complete this 2013 collection of paintings. Thanks so much for your support.

                                    The Lion Lives,  Oil on canvas 60 x 60 inches

Bio:
 
I am an interdisciplinary multimedia artist focusing in video/film, painting, photography, printmaking, sculpture, digital work, and drawing.  Between sculpture, photography, digital, I have many works and methods in progress.  I recently was named assistant director on a short film here in Seattle, as well as producing and directing my own shorts.  I approach my work crossing many mediums to derive a collective whole.  Right now, I want to create a 2013 collection of paintings.  For years now I’ve been on the hunt for a new and experimental method of painting, and after completing over a hundred or so works in that investigation, I found it.  
 
It has been my vision to execute 30-50 paintings all in large scale.  The reason for the size of the images to be so grand is so the viewer can be encompassed by these somewhat other worlds that are created.  Its is my goal to execute at least 30 so that I can have a large body of work to then be able to present to galleries, collectors, and agencies in order to gain representation, launching my career in the international art world.  In the act of being a successful artist, you have to have a concise method and a deliberate art practice to go forth from.  So in developing this method I have found that definitive style that can then be explored in a series of 30 - 50 paintings.  This is so exciting for me because I am finally ready to step out into the art world with strong, streamlined work that I am passionate about. 
  
                                          Lunar Eclipse, Oil on panel 48 x 60 in

Logistics:
 
This brings us to the point of why we're here today.  Painting is expensive, bottom line.  It’s gonna take a lot to pull this off, but I feel it can happen.  On top of applying for grant opportunities, I’m launching this indiegogo to fund this campaign.  In order to do this I need very specific materials and that can get pricey.  Oil paint is a very refined product with some smaller tubes starting at ten dollars going up to a hundred or more. The thing is with my process I use a lot of paint, and tubes won’t cut it.  So I have to buy gallons of oil paint, costing around 75.00 a piece.  With a collection this big and dealing with larger scale, this is definitely a necessity.  So in order to have a full spectrum and to be able to develop the work to it’s full potential, I will need around 20-30 different colors in gallon form.  Not to worry.  It all can happen and it can be beautiful.  Other materials are going to include door skin paneling to make canvas supports, 2x2 wood to reinforce the panels, canvas to stretch over the panels so that the canvas won’t warp from the weight of the paint, at least 30 gallons of gesso to coat and seal the canvas from the oil paint, screws and wood glue to attach the wooden panel structures, staples for the canvas, 3 box fans for ventilation, one shop fan, chop saw, skill saw, 2 work tables.  I want to execute starting in July and working through the fall of this year.
 
Door skin panel               30 pieces x 30.00                  750.00
2x2 wood                       120 pieces x 10.00                 1200.00
Canvas 96 in. 11 oz        120 yards x 12.70                  1560.00
Oil Paint                         30 gallons x 75.00                 2250.00
Gesso                            30 gallons x 30.00                 900.00
 
Chop saw                                                                   200.00
Screws                                                                      100.00
2 work tables                                                              45.00
Skill saw                                                                    100.00
2 saw guides                                                              30.00
Wood glue                                                                  25.00
Ventamatic shop vac                                                  150.00
3 box fans                                                                  75.00
 
 
Total Supplies:                                                           7,385.00
 
Incidentals:                                                                115.00
 
Total:                                                                        7,500.00
                        
                                               Dark Star, Oil on canvas 82 x 34 in 

How you can help:
 
So as you can see this is somewhat of a daunting task.  But with this method of crowd funding, as a team we can pull this together and make a dream come true.  I have been a practicing artist all my life, the difference now is that I am ready to emerge into the art world with a strong body of work.  And through your help, this can happen. You have that opportunity through this campaign, to be apart of history, and help an artist succeed in doing great work.  Thank you so much for your support.  Thank you so much for being you.
                                       
                                                   Krystal Kastle, Oil 24 x 78.5 in
                                       
                       As Night Ascends Upon The Streets Of L.A., Oil on wood 24 x 78.5 in
 
                                
                             The Skies Were Open Bare, Oil on canvas/panel 30 x 78.5 in

The tiers for donation:
 
The way indiegogo and crowdfunding sites like this work is through donations of many people, large (and small) task can be accomplished.  In the donation list of reciprocated gratitude on the right, I have included prints of the new collection of paintings to be a gift to you throughout the different tier levels.  I have deliberately withheld selling any of my work so when I did decide to enter the art market, it would be on my terms and I could dictate how the work would be shown, sold, and subsequently handled.  There is no doubt in my mind that art is a business, and through that I never wanted my product to be watered down.  Instead I want it to be refined, rare, and sought after.  It is through this understanding that I am now going to enter the market, with a strong, grounded, body of work.  Thank you so much.

story:
We are so close to opening! Help us raise the $15,700 we need to secure a matching grant from the Howard and Bush Foundation.

What: Woodside is a historic Neo-gothic stone church in Troy, NY. Vacant for years, it's now in the midst of a transformation into a dynamic venue for art and performance events, which will host everything from summer films and neighborhood BBQ picnics to internationally renowned artists and performers.

The story: In 1860 Henry Burden stood up at his wife's funeral and announced he would build a church in her honor. Nine years later it was completed. For over 125 years the church was a central part of the South Troy neighborhood where it recorded the births, deaths, marriages, trials and triumphs of the community.

The problem: In  2003 it looked like the Woodside Church was certain to be demolished. Some of the facade stone had tumbled and the congregation, unable to take care of it, was in negotiations with a buyer who wished to knock it down. The good people of Troy, NY refused to let that happen. After years of struggle Woodside was returned to the care of the great-great grandchildren of Henry Burden who were determined that it survive. In 2007 these grandchildren, Ada & Chris, chose the Contemporary Artists Center to be the next stewards of the site

Renovation: On a limited budget and with a lot of sweat and determination we have been working on this project for the past few years. We are now within sight of the finish line! In 2009 we renovated the secondary building & it's now in use as an international residency program, welcoming over 350 artists from all over the U.S.A. and abroad. A few months ago we finished up the exterior facade renovation of the church as thousands of stones were built back up in the gable end walls. You can see some of that work here: http://cacwoodside.tumblr.com/

Now: This fall we begin the much anticipated interior renovation. The church will see plumbing for the first time ever and modern electrical and lighting systems. The walls and ceiling will get patched and painted and the floors will get refinished. Woodside will shine again, and be ready to welcome the public next year.

The result: (This is the exciting part!) Imagine this building alive with artists & artwork, filled with music & community members and you. Imagine being a part of exhibitions, conversations, lectures and creations. Imagine opening the big wooden doors to the soaring open space of the sanctuary and seeing it full of immersive, participatory, and interactive events and installations. Imagine dancing the night away to your favorite band, or just sitting on the stoop and watching the light filter through the stained glass windows. Imagine passing Woodside, perched on the hill and looking up and seeing it repaired and renewed, and thinking, "Yes, I made that happen!"


(Restoration Festival, Sept 6 & 7: concert fundraiser in unfinished Church space)

Here's the deal: You help us reach our fundraising goal and we promise you this building will be preserved for you to enjoy and we will entertain and enlighten you with some of the world's best new art & music in the years to come.

The challenge: Renovation projects are always a challenge. Old buildings reveal new problems along the course of construction, work can take longer than expected, weather must cooperate, new conundrums can arise. This is something that is just part of the process, however. We have already successfully completed about 80% of the project and have confidence in our team, our contractors, and architects to finish the work in the professional manner they have displayed throughout.

-    -    -    -    -    -

NOTE: When you are taken to the payment link it may say "Berkshire School of Contemporary Art, Inc" - that is our original incorporated (IRS) name from 24 years ago in Massachusetts. It gets indicated for your records in that way so you can receive the donation write off. We are one and the same entity.

story:
ME and A TOUCH OF ITALY!

Hi, I'm Ilaria Presciuttini, I come from Italy but now I'm attending a Master in Events and Exhibition Management. My biggest dream is to become one day an event planner and I need to prove to everybody I have the ability!

One of the modules I am taking requires me to become an entrepreneur and I decided to become a freelance event planner and follow my ideas and dreams. To do it I would like to organize a photography exhibition.

The protagonists of it will be 4 of my friends, they love taking photo and we thought this idea can be good for them as well! I will be free to organize the event as I want! What it's in my mind now is to be creative and artistic, that's why I was thinking about a background with of other artists (as dancers or musician) that can help the atmosphere. The photo will represent all Italian landscapes and beautiful places. There will be 4 little notebooks where each artist can express all his feelings while they were taking the photo.

If you will help me, us, you will give us a possibility to show you all our capacity, give to the city a new show to see, you will give us the opportunity to do something different!

FOLLOW MY PROJECT HERE!!!

http://ilariapresciuttini.tumblr.com/

MORE 

All the money you would like to give to me will be used to cover the costs of the venue, the equipment hire and to print the photo. Nothing will arrive to us, but we will just use for the artistic side, everything we can't effort, being all students!

We would like to create something original, that you can't see everywhere or in any moment!

I hope to reach the goal, but if I don't I will spend the money for the same reason!

For you

My project will give you ideas of a new way to see arts in general, and will give you the possibility to see the show, or Birmingham for a week-end!


Please help my project become real and help me reach the goal!

Share it EVERYWHERE!

story:
My name is Keyo, I've been an artist all my life.

My goal as of right now is to gather support for new product for my store and for conventions. New canvas, new shirts, NEW PRODUCT.

What We Need & What You Get

All I'm asking is for $1000, to get things started. The better quality is all I'd like to deliver.

With every donation to help, I'll compile a list and give each person a gift voucher to use on my online store!

If my goal is not met, the money that has been donated will still go to affordable machines to help me self produce things at my home.

The Impact

This is the first year I've started doing conventions and funding for more product. I'm glad to see the progression but is hard on very little pay.

Going to said conventions has given me more motivation to push myself harder to get new things for you guys and the investment for my upcoming comicbook.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

 

I love the responses I get from you guys and would love to hear more ways to help things roll smoothly.

<3 Keyo

story:
My Story

I'm a young photographer struggling to get started. I'm currently working a part-time job and going to school part-time as well. I also live in the city which means most of my income go to rent. So not a lot of funds go to my passion, photography. After struggling to to find direction in my life I fell back to something that always seemed to be there, a camera. Now without a doubt I know this is what and who I want to be. I just need a little help to get there. I went back and forth with asking for help, because I'm not one to ask for anything but this is something that will impact my life and my family. This is my dream and any help reaching a part of it would be utterly amazing.

New goal - $500


The Impact

My dream is to inspire and make people think when they view my work. If I make someone uncomfortable and question something in themselves or the world then I will feel I've done what I set out to do. Future projects include but are not limited to gender studies, community research through photos, street photography, fashion series, still life and lifestyle. This would impact my life in so many ways and with your help I would be eternally grateful.



What I Need 

Every little bit helps and with your kind contribution I will be able to put my plans into motion!


  • Lighting - monoheads, soft boxes, grids, reflectors, stands etc.
  • Studio budget - a few shoots done for building my portfolio and projects
  • Model & make-up artist costs - kit fees, sitting fees etc.
  • Domain set-up fees & business cards
  • Possible gallery show!


& What You Get

Due to my limited budget what I can offer is also limited. I hope to give you a feeling of doing something great for a fellow human being! See perks on side-bar for more info!


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Blog about this campaign, throw a link on facebook or tweet it, and tell some friends. Anything will help!


Find me here:


http://grrlphoto.4ormat.com/


http://grrlphoto.tumblr.com/


Thanks so much for viewing this project, I appreciate it :)
story_txt:
My Story
I'm a young photographer struggling to get started. I'm currently working a part-time job and going to school part-time as well. I also live in the city which means most of my income go to rent. So not a lot of funds go to my passion, photography. After struggling to to find direction in my life I fell back to something that always seemed to be there, a camera. Now without a doubt I know this is what and who I want to be. I just need a little help to get there. I went back and forth with asking for help, because I'm not one to ask for anything but this is something that will impact my life and my family. This is my dream and any help reaching a part of it would be utterly amazing. 
New goal - $500



The Impact
My dream is to inspire and make people think when they view my work. If I make someone uncomfortable and question something in themselves or the world then I will feel I've done what I set out to do. Future projects include but are not limited to gender studies, community research through photos, street photography, fashion series, still life and lifestyle. This would impact my life in so many ways and with your help I would be eternally grateful.




What I Need 
Every little bit helps and with your kind contribution I will be able to put my plans into motion!


Lighting - monoheads, soft boxes, grids, reflectors, stands etc.
Studio budget - a few shoots done for building my portfolio and projects
Model & make-up artist costs - kit fees, sitting fees etc.
Domain set-up fees & business cards
Possible gallery show!


& What You Get
Due to my limited budget what I can offer is also limited. I hope to give you a feeling of doing something great for a fellow human being! See perks on side-bar for more info!



Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word! Blog about this campaign, throw a link on facebook or tweet it, and tell some friends. Anything will help!

Find me here:

http://grrlphoto.4ormat.com/

http://grrlphoto.tumblr.com/

Thanks so much for viewing this project, I appreciate it :)

story:
Who am I and what are we doing?

I am a performer, designer, director and teacher living in Brooklyn.  While most of my training is in acting (Carnegie Mellon BFA, 2000; Yale MFA 2008) I have spent the last four years exploring design, production and performance art.  The Ghost Walk is a manifestation of lost spirits who return to our world in places where they know they will not be seen to engage in ritual acts of remembrance and forgiveness.  We record these rituals in non-traditional space for an unspecified audience and later reveal them as memory through the medium of video art and photography. 

The performers create these rituals in rehearsal by filtering personal story through the vocabulary of Butoh and Mystical Imagery.  By returning to the locations from which the costume materials were collected to engage in ceremony, we transform neglected space into a platform for magic and restore forgotten memories to life. 

 

 Why we need your help and where is your donation going?

Because the costumes for this piece are made almost completely of collected refuse the baseline budget is very minimal.  97% of the budget goes toward paying cast and crew.  

If we reach $2,240.00 cast and crew receive a travel stipend! Not bad!

If we reach $4,295.00 cast and crew receive a travel stipend AND pay for the day of the shoot!  Even better!

If we reach $7,078.00 cast and crew receive a travel stipend, pay for the day of the shoot AND pay for rehearsal!  Hallelujah the world is as it should be!!!

 (Any amount raised over our goal will be distributed by percentage to cast and crew as a bonus.)

 Too often in our culture artists are expected to work without pay and I want to do everything in my power to compensate these extraordinary talents for their time and effort.  I am deeply dedicated to taking care of the artists who work with me, from protecting their safety and well-being on set to allowing them the freedom to contribute their creative expression to the overall vision of the piece.  Putting my team on salary is a huge part of that respect and dedication.  With your help I can give them the compensation they deserve! 

Unable to make a donation? You can still help!

We understand that not everyone will be able to make a monetary contribution to our project.  That's O.K!  If you are interested in what we are doing and would like to support us post a link to this campaign on your Facebook page, send an e-mail, Tweet or post on your blog.  The more people we can reach the better.  Every action counts and we need your help!

story:
Short Summary

Thank Wally for all he has done in Philadelphia and help him enjoy his new home of Portland, Oregon! PLEASE NOTE: This is a SECRET. PLEASE DON'T CONTACT WALLY ABOUT THIS UNTIL THE CAMPAIGN IS OVER!

  • My name is Daniel Student and I count myself as an artist in Philadelphia who has been inspired by Wally Zialcita. He is the co-founder of the PDC Playwright's Residency at Plays & Players, where I am Artistic Director, and his desire to help other artists make discoveries about their art in Philadelphia will live on in this program and so many others.
  • I would like to help Wally continue to inspire others in Portland but also help him with his own goals as an artist and playwright, goals he set aside so frequently in Philadelphia. He mentioned the TBA (Time-Based Art) Festival, an amazing sounding Portland festival that will occur just days after he has moved there. These funds will go to an "Immersion" pass to see all performances, exhibits, and programs in the festival. http://pica.org/programs/tba-festival/

Wally will make valuable connections with artists around the world and in his new home and has expressed interest in blogging his responses to the work, already helping Portland's community get exposure as he always did here in Philadelphia.

What We Need & What You Get

This is a way to feel someone feel loved and celebrated and thanked by his community. But beyond that:

  • We need $250 for the pass. Anything more than that I get, I will instruct Wally should be used for office space (or coffees at a coffee shop) for him to use for writing.
  • There is only one perk here. If you donate more than $10 and leave me an email I will pass on to Wally that you contributed to this gift. I will let him decide what perks go from there.

The Impact

Wally will truly jump headfirst into his new community, and this time it will be us supporting his art, instead of him supporting ours! He has always come to see our work, and has added ticket sales to our various projects, and opportunities for other writers to be produced in his fringe shows, or collaborate on PDC projects. Let's return the favor this time.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Once this campaign is over, email Wally to say goodbye! But don't do it until after September 1!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
La Factory di Leggere Strutture: CHIUDE?

 

NOI CI ABBIAMO MESSO LA FACTORY.

 

TU COSA CI METTI?

 

ABBIAMO 2 MESI DI TEMPO.

 

Chi perde uno spazio di lavoro perde una casa.

Non può più riposare, pensare, ospitare,

immaginare il futuro. 

Leggere Strutture Factory è un centro culturale indipendente ubicato in un ex stabile industriale nella città di Bologna.

Alla Factory ti accolgono un caffè vegan, uno spazio di produzione artistica e creativa, una compagnia di danza e un centro di formazione professionale per danzatori, uno sportello di consulenze per l’impresa sociale e culturale, tutto in una modalità di coworking e di scambio di risorse.

La Factory ha pavimenti in legno biocompatibile ed è riscaldata da pannelli solari.
Gli arredi sono costruiti da giovani designer o provenienti da percorsi di scambio senza denaro. I materiali di uso comune seguono il principio del recupero e dell’acquisto verde.

La Factory e’ un progetto che parla di nuove economie, che coprogetta e include, che riporta al centro ciò che sta ai margini, che ama le periferie, i confini, che non crede nel denaro come unica risposta, che sceglie il piccolo e sostiene le differenze.

Il suo progetto di Social Business si occupa di riavvio di competenze, nuove povertà, persone fuoriuscite dal mercato del lavoro. Inventa nuovi percorsi per la sostenibilità, si mette alla prova.

La Factory non possiede nulla, ha solo ciò che serve. 

 

La Factory in 5 anni di attività ha dato lavoro a più di 100 persone. 

Ha rappresentato un punto di riferimento per attività culturali, artistiche, ha formato e inserito in compagnie di danza nazionali e internazionali quasi 50 giovani danzatori, ha sostenuto percorsi di reintegrazione sociale e lavorativa, ha realizzato progetti, ha inventato nuovi modi di lavorare, ha fatto incontrare persone, idee, esperienze, ha costruito e disfatto, ricomposto e reinventato, si è persa e si è ritrovata.

Ha accolto. Ha regalato. Ha preso posizioni.

Si è presa tutta la responsabilità.

 

 

Dal 2009:

  • ha riconvertito in centro creativo un magazzino chiuso da anni, sostenendone le spese di ristrutturazione, di adeguamento locali, di cambio di destinazione d’uso con un investimento privato di oltre 200.000 euro e la stipula di un mutuo ventennale;

  • ha attivato un percorso di coworking ospitando altri professionisti all’interno della struttura;

  • ha aperto un spazio bar riallestendo il piano terra dello stabile. 

Dal 2012:

  • ha richiesto una riduzione del canone di locazione. Riduzione non concessa;

  • ha subito un aumento del canone di locazione per l’utilizzo di due posti auto di cui non usufruisce. Non è stata possibile alcuna negoziazione.

  • a seguito della modifica delle norme antincendio per i locali di pubblico spettacolo ha dovuto sospendere parte delle attività che potranno riprendere solo una volta effettuate le modifiche strutturali necessarie all’adeguamento normativo.

     

NON RIUSCIAMO A FAR FRONTE A TUTTE LE SPESE. 

NON POSSIAMO PIÙ LAVORARE. 

 

Quali soluzioni? 

  1. Un progetto di azionariato popolare per il sostegno economico del percorso intrapreso.

  2. Un piano di ristrutturazione aziendale aperto e partecipato in cui convergano:

  • progetti di sostegno alla programmazione;

  • collaborazioni volontarie;

  • azioni di coprogettazione.

     

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ABBIAMO LAVORATO E LAVORIAMO:

Per uno spazio condiviso

Facciamo coworking, accogliamo e promuoviamo nuovi progetti, organizziamo residenze per artisti, ospitiamo laboratori e percorsi interdisciplinari.

 Per una corresponsabilità

Realizziamo tavoli di coprogettazione, puntiamo al coinvolgimento della comunità locale, crediamo nella condivisione di idee e competenze per la nascita di nuove opportunità di lavoro.

 Per la creazione di lavoro e riavvio di competenze

Segnaliamo opportunità, realizziamo percorsi formativi per giovani professionisti dello spettacolo e ne curiamo l'inserimento lavorativo in compagnie nazionali ed internazionali, realizziamo workshop e percorsi formativi per  l’autoimprenditorialità e per persone fuoriuscite dal mercato del lavoro, collaboriamo ad un laboratorio permanente sulle fragilità metropolitane, abbiamo creato uno sportello per lo sviluppo di progetti d'impresa sociale.

 Per un progetto accessibile a tutti

Realizziamo corsi gratuiti, sostieniamo progetti per l'inclusione sociale e percorsi creativi per la disabilità motoria, attiviamo borse lavoro per persone in stato di disagio.

 Per un percorso di scambio

Attiviamo percorsi di scambio e sosteniamo le economie non monetarie, progettiamo e organizziamo eventi che non utilizzino il denaro come unica risorsa.

 

NOI CI ABBIAMO MESSO TUTTO QUESTO.

E TU, COSA CI METTI?

SOSTIENI LA FACTORY

PARTECIPA AL PROGETTO DI CROWDFUNDING

VISITA IL SITO www.leggerestrutture.it

 

INVIA LE TUE PROPOSTE, REGALACI IL TUO TEMPO,

LE TUE COMPETENZE: cosacimetti@leggerestrutture.it

  

ABBIAMO 2 MESI DI TEMPO.

Chi perde uno spazio di lavoro perde una casa.

Non può più riposare, pensare, ospitare, immaginare il futuro.

 

 

info:

Leggere Strutture Factory

Via Ferrarese 169/A, Bologna

0510951158/59 - 3465780688 - 3296060396

info@leggerestrutture.it

ufficio stampa :

press@leggerestrutture.it - 3491344542

www.leggerestrutture.it

*************************************************************************************************************

IS THE FACTORY GOING TO CLOSE?

WE MADE THE FACTORY. 

WHAT CAN YOU ADD?

 

We have got 2 months.

Who loses his place of work looses his home.

He can’t rest, he can’t think, he can’t host, he can’t imagine.

 

Leggere Strutture Factory is an independent cultural centre sited in an ex industrial building in Bologna. At the Factory you can find a vegan cafè, a space for artistic and creative production, a dance company and a training centre for dancers, a counselling service for social and cultural enterprise. All the activities are conducted in a co-working and shared way. The Factory has eco-friendly wood flooring and it is heated by solar panels. The whole furniture is made by young designers or obtained through exchange and other forms of non-monetary trade, conforming to a general eco-friendly policies. The Factory project is also focused on new economies: it does not conceive money as the only answer, it includes and brings back to the centre what is at the margins, it privileges what is small and works among boundaries and differences. The Factory runs a Social Business project that is focused on restarting skills, new poverties and unemployed people. It invents new ways of sustainability and it puts itself to the test. 

The Factory owes nothing and possesses only the necessary. 

 

In five years of activity, the Factory has given a job to more than 100 people.

It has become a datum point for cultural and artistic activities, it has trained almost 50 dancers and it has found for them a job in important national and international dance companies. It has supported social reintegration and employment restatement paths, it has carried out projects, it has invented new methods of work, it has brought together people, ideas and experiences. It has built and destroyed, reinvented and rebuilt. It has got lost and then it has found the way. It has received and given, it has taken a stand, as well as it has taken the whole responsibility.

 

Since 2009:

  • The Factory has transformed a closed warehouse into a creative centre, bearing the costs of reconstruction, of structural adaptation and bureaucratic expenses through a private investment of 200.000 euros and a twenty-year loan;

  • It has started a co-working process, hosting other professionals inside the building;

  • It has opened a bar at the ground floor.

  

Since 2012:

  • The Factory has called for a reduction in rent, which has not been granted;

  • There has been an increase of rent for the use of a parking which we do not use. There was no possible negotiation;

  • Due to a modification of the standard fire for places of public entertainment, the Factory had to suspend some of its activities, which can restart only after an adaptation to the standards.

We can’t bear such expenses.

We can’t go on working.

 

What solutions? 

  1. A popular shareholding for sustaining the project developed until now.

  2. An open and participated corporate restructuring which could put together:  

  • projects for planning activities;

  • voluntary collaborations;
  • co-projecting activities.

 

WE HAVE WORKED AND STILL WORK:

For a shared place

We do co-working and promote new projects, organize residences for artists, host workshops and interdisciplinary collaborations.

For a shared responsibility

We co-project, trying to involve the local community, we believe in sharing ideas and skills in order to develop new job opportunities.

For new job opportunities and skill restarting

We indicate opportunities and realize training courses for young dancers, trying to facilitate their placement in national and international dance companies. We realize workshops on enterprise creation for unemployed and disadvantaged people, we are involved in a project on urban fragilities and we have created a counselling service for social business projects.

For a project accessible to all

We realize training courses for free and support projects on social inclusion and disability, we also work on the activation of bursary works for disadvantaged people.

For exchange trading

We organize exchange activities and support non-monetary economies, planning and projecting events in which money is not the only resource.

 

WE MADE ALL THESE THINGS

WHAT CAN YOU ADD?

SUPPORT THE FACTORY

TAKE PART TO THE CROWD FUNDING PROJECT 

VISIT THE WEBSITE www.leggerestrutture.it

 

SEND US YOUR SUGGESTIONS GIVE US A BIT OF YOUR TIME, GIVE US SOME OF YOUR SKILLS cosacimetti@leggerestrutture.it

 

We have got 2 months.

Who loses his place of work looses his home. He can’t rest, he can’t think, he can’t host, he can’t imagine.

 

 

 

Info:

 

Leggere Strutture Factory

 

Via Ferrarese 169/A, Bologna

 

+39 0510951158/59 – +39 3491344542 - +39 3465780688

 

info@leggerestrutture.it

 

www.leggerestrutture.it

press@leggerestrutture.it - +39 3491344542

Who loses his place of work looses his home.
He can’t rest, he can’t think, he can’t host, he can’t imagine.
 
Leggere Strutture Factory is an independent cultural centre sited in an ex industrial building in Bologna. At the Factory you can find a vegan cafè, a space for artistic and creative production, a dance company and a training centre for dancers, a counselling service for social and cultural enterprise. All the activities are conducted in a co-working and shared way. The Factory has eco-friendly wood flooring and it is heated by solar panels. The whole furniture is made by young designers or obtained through exchange and other forms of non-monetary trade, conforming to a general eco-friendly policies. The Factory project is also focused on new economies: it does not conceive money as the only answer, it includes and brings back to the centre what is at the margins, it privileges what is small and works among boundaries and differences. The Factory runs a Social Business project that is focused on restarting skills, new poverties and unemployed people. It invents new ways of sustainability and it puts itself to the test. 
The Factory owes nothing and possesses only the necessary. 
 
In five years of activity, the Factory has given a job to more than 100 people.
 It has become a datum point for cultural and artistic activities, it has trained almost 50 dancers and it has found for them a job in important national and international dance companies. It has supported social reintegration and employment restatement paths, it has carried out projects, it has invented new methods of work, it has brought together people, ideas and experiences. It has built and destroyed, reinvented and rebuilt. It has got lost and then it has found the way. It has received and given, it has taken a stand, as well as it has taken the whole responsibility.

 
Since 2009:


The Factory has transformed a closed warehouse into a creative centre, bearing the costs of reconstruction, of structural adaptation and bureaucratic expenses through a private investment of 200.000 euros and a twenty-year loan;


It has started a co-working process, hosting other professionals inside the building;


It has opened a bar at the ground floor.

  
Since 2012:


The Factory has called for a reduction in rent, which has not been granted;


There has been an increase of rent for the use of a parking which we do not use. There was no possible negotiation;


Due to a modification of the standard fire for places of public entertainment, the Factory had to suspend some of its activities, which can restart only after an adaptation to the standards.

We can’t bear such expenses. 
We can’t go on working.
 
What solutions? 


A popular shareholding for sustaining the project developed until now.


An open and participated corporate restructuring which could put together:  



projects for planning activities;


voluntary collaborations;
co-projecting activities.
 
WE HAVE WORKED AND STILL WORK:
For a shared place
We do co-working and promote new projects, organize residences for artists, host workshops and interdisciplinary collaborations.
For a shared responsibility
We co-project, trying to involve the local community, we believe in sharing ideas and skills in order to develop new job opportunities.
For new job opportunities and skill restarting
We indicate opportunities and realize training courses for young dancers, trying to facilitate their placement in national and international dance companies. We realize workshops on enterprise creation for unemployed and disadvantaged people, we are involved in a project on urban fragilities and we have created a counselling service for social business projects.
For a project accessible to all
We realize training courses for free and support projects on social inclusion and disability, we also work on the activation of bursary works for disadvantaged people.
For exchange trading
We organize exchange activities and support non-monetary economies, planning and projecting events in which money is not the only resource.
 
WE MADE ALL THESE THINGS
WHAT CAN YOU ADD?

SUPPORT THE FACTORY
TAKE PART TO THE CROWD FUNDING PROJECT 
VISIT THE WEBSITE www.leggerestrutture.it
 
SEND US YOUR SUGGESTIONS GIVE US A BIT OF YOUR TIME, GIVE US SOME OF YOUR SKILLS cosacimetti@leggerestrutture.it
 
We have got 2 months.
Who loses his place of work looses his home. He can’t rest, he can’t think, he can’t host, he can’t imagine.
 
 
 
Info:
 
Leggere Strutture Factory
 
Via Ferrarese 169/A, Bologna
 
+39 0510951158/59 – +39 3491344542 - +39 3465780688 
 
info@leggerestrutture.it
 
www.leggerestrutture.it
