story:
Short Summary

As musicians and artists, it is important for us in the early stages of our professional careers to broaden our horizons whilst at the same time giving back to others by sharing our music through performance or in an educative manner.
In this instance, we have been presented a unique opportunity to collaborate with composers and performers in various countries of the Pacific region, as well as share our own thoughts on music with the students at these institutions we are planning to visit.
With your help, we will be able to share our love and passion for new music with a completely new group of people. Some of which may have not seen music like this before, or who may be interested in engaging in new perspectives of performance practice. Specifically that involving percussion and piano duo repertoire, music for small chamber ensemble, and solo percussion.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising money to support our travel costs from the United States to the Pacific. Since we will be hopping from country to country for a two and a half to three week period, we will also need to be able to afford lodging for the both of us whilst visiting to teach and perform. Our fundraising goal is $6,000.

Rewards:

$5 to $10: 

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.

$15 to $30: 

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.

- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.

$35 to $50:

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.

- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.

- demo recordings of the percussion solo repertoire from the tour.

$60 to $90:

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.

- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.

- demo recordings of the percussion solo repertoire from the tour.

- Video recordings of either the piano and percussion duo repertoire OR the solo repertoire

$100 +: 

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.

- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.

- demo recordings of the percussion solo repertoire from the tour.

- Video recordings of both the piano and percussion duo repertoire OR the solo repertoire

Secret Perk:

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/pacific-tour...

If our goal is not entirely met, we would of course seek alternative funding options. However, we know that with your support, we can reach our $6,000 goal :)

Garrett has previously engaged in a similar project that brought six musicians each from a different country to perform a monumental work by Iannis Xenakis at a percussion festival in Eindhoven. The fundraising goal of $7,000 was exceeded by a few hundred. 

Risks & Challenges

Of course, traveling alone is expensive when embarking on a tour of this caliber. But as musicians, the real challenge for us and what we really want to focus on is sharing our ideas with a new group of individuals who we're sure love music just as much as we do. Being able to reach an audience is one of the most rewarding aspects of performing and teaching in music. And it is always a welcomed challenge.

We are both doctoral fellows at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. Because of our experience and relentless involvement in musical performance and education, we are able and have proven to execute on stage and in the classroom. We are hopeful that we will be able to do the same for students and audiences in the Pacific region as well.

With your support, we can overcome the obvious financial hurdles of international travel costs, which will make the experience better both for us and our audiences.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps when it comes to these fundraisers. $5 makes an absolute world of difference. However, if you yourself are unable to contribute at this time, just simply spreading the word and circulating this project to others who might be willing to pitch in is also a great method of support.

With your help, we will be able to share our love and passion for new music with a completely new group of people. Some of which may have not seen music like this before, or who may be interested in engaging in new perspectives of performance practice. Specifically that involving percussion and piano duo repertoire, music for small chamber ensemble, and solo percussion.
   What We Need & What You Get
We are raising money to support our travel costs from the United States to the Pacific. Since we will be hopping from country to country for a two and a half to three week period, we will also need to be able to afford lodging for the both of us whilst visiting to teach and perform. Our fundraising goal is $6,000.
Rewards:
$5 to $10: 
- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.
$15 to $30: 
- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.
- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.
$35 to $50:

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.
- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.- demo recordings of the percussion solo repertoire from the tour.$60 to $90:

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.
- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.- demo recordings of the percussion solo repertoire from the tour.- Video recordings of either the piano and percussion duo repertoire OR the solo repertoire
$100 +: 

- a personal thank you greeting from the both of us.
- demo recordings of the percussion and piano duo repertoire from the tour.- demo recordings of the percussion solo repertoire from the tour.- Video recordings of both the piano and percussion duo repertoire OR the solo repertoire
Secret Perk:
https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/pacific-tour...
If our goal is not entirely met, we would of course seek alternative funding options. However, we know that with your support, we can reach our $6,000 goal :)
Garrett has previously engaged in a similar project that brought six musicians each from a different country to perform a monumental work by Iannis Xenakis at a percussion festival in Eindhoven. The fundraising goal of $7,000 was exceeded by a few hundred. 
  Risks & Challenges Of course, traveling alone is expensive when embarking on a tour of this caliber. But as musicians, the real challenge for us and what we really want to focus on is sharing our ideas with a new group of individuals who we're sure love music just as much as we do. Being able to reach an audience is one of the most rewarding aspects of performing and teaching in music. And it is always a welcomed challenge.
We are both doctoral fellows at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. Because of our experience and relentless involvement in musical performance and education, we are able and have proven to execute on stage and in the classroom. We are hopeful that we will be able to do the same for students and audiences in the Pacific region as well.
With your support, we can overcome the obvious financial hurdles of international travel costs, which will make the experience better both for us and our audiences.   Other Ways You Can Help Every little bit helps when it comes to these fundraisers. $5 makes an absolute world of difference. However, if you yourself are unable to contribute at this time, just simply spreading the word and circulating this project to others who might be willing to pitch in is also a great method of support.

story:
The Mural

As West Oakland/Emeryville's largest mural revitalization and beautification effort, Attitudinal Healing Connection (AHC) continues to bring change and beauty by bridging youth with public art, through the Oakland Super Heroes Mural Project (OSH). OSH involves the beautification of seven 4,000 sq. ft. walls and aims to resolve issues that plague our city, engage 200 youth to be agents of change in their community, create over 30 jobs, enhance our neighborhoods and reduce blight.

This mural will transform the space under the 580 freeway by giving meaning and intention to an otherwise disassociated and divested part of the city. To be painted on West Street between 35th and 36th streets, the mural will not only impact the lives of all those who pass by but will profoundly empower and influence the concepts of what is thought possible by ArtEsteem Visual Art students. This project allows them to see their ideas, hopes and dreams inspire the community by artistically solving three of the most pervasive issues plaguing Oakland: violence, blight and graffiti.

Each concrete canvas painting is and will be conceptually designed by our youth from local public schools. This project empowers our youth and community members to take action regarding the health of our city, which creates a thriving atmosphere for residents and businesses. 


Where Your Money is Going

The following is a breakdown of the needs and uses of funds for the mural project:

  • Five months of AHC staff time and materials to administer community and youth engagement (per mural)
  • One month coordinating with school administration to engage youth participants (per mural)
  • Four months coordinating and training youth in the mural painting process at various schools (per mural)
  • Community engagement via convening and surveys (In spring 2012, AHC conducted surveys involving 150 residents in the Hoover Corridor. The results gave insight to their community concerns and what they would envision in the murals as an effort to beautify their community. Community meetings will continue to be convened as the project develops.)
  • Soliciting local artists to lead and participate in each mural installation
  • Project management: managing and detailing administrative logistics
  • Salary for art director
  • Salaries for lead artists
  • Salaries for 10-12 assisting mural artists (per mural)
  • Stipends for youth
  • Materials and supplies: 100 gallons of paint (per mural), aluminum scaffolding, scissor lift, ladders, paint brushes, rollers, tape, drop cloths
  • Project marketing and publicity: design and development of mural website, marketing videos, photos, fundraising campaign, media outreach, production of events, flyers, stickers, prints, etc.


The First Two Murals

Our first mural in the Oakland Super Heroes Mural Project series was completed in July 2012. It is located on San Pablo Avenue between 35th and 36th streets, under the 580 freeway. We successfully raised $75k to launch our project. In the process we created 14 local jobs and engaged 20 local youth.

Our second mural was completed in February of 2014. It is located on Market Street between 35th and 36th streets, under the 580 Freeway. We created 12 local jobs and engaged 16 local youth while raising the $75k. 

 “Hope, tolerance and pride in our community and within ourselves. The murals represent our hopes for what we can be.” — Former Emeryville Mayor Kurt Brinkman on the Oakland Super Heroes Mural Project

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

Founded by Carlton Mackey, visual artist and Director of the Ethics & the Arts Initiative at the Emory University Center for Ethics, 50 Shades of Black is committed to exploring the complex relationship between race, skin tone, sexuality, and the formation of identity. Through collaborations with visual artists, scholars and the general public, this project hopes to offer a deeper understanding of what diversity means. It is in the recognition of this diversity that 50 Shades of Black acknowledges the historical role that race and skin tone have played in shaping the way we engage the world, how we perceive beauty, and our own self worth.  Visit www.50shadesofblack.com

When you Pre-Order our First Edition Book or Purchase our Custom Garment & Poster, You Are: 

EQUIPPING YOUTH, ENGAGING COMMUNITY, CHRONICLING HISTORY, AND EMPOWERING ARTISTS.  THANK YOU!

---

FIRST EDITION OF 50 SHADES OF BLACK-THE CONVERSATION

*50 Shades of Black Coffee Table Book

The collaborative artistic, personal narrative, and scholarly project exploring issues of sexuality, skin tone, and identity.

100+ pages 

Introductory Chapter by Dr. Yaba Blay, Consulting Producer for CNN Black in America 5 – “Who is Black in America?” – a television documentary inspired by the scope of the (1)ne Drop Project and Assistant Professor of Africana Studies at Drexel University.

Contributions by noted artists Chath pierSath, Fahamu Pecou, Ross Oscar Knight, Chris Charles, Andrew Thomas Clifton, and many more.

Includes African, African-American, Latino, Asian, Bi-Racial, and Multi cultural Perspectives

Interwoven with voices from the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Communities

Features a Special Tribute to the Legendary Joyce Bryant by her niece Robyn Labeaud

*Mockup of Book Above.  Exact dimensions and Cover subject to change

 

*BEAUTIFUL IN EVERY SHADE Signature Garment

Designed by 50 Shades of Black featured artists Chris Charles of Creative Silence in North Carolina and created by hand in Atlanta Georgia by Chazz Pope of Di Versa Phi Screenprinting and Design, this "BEAUTIFUL SHIRT" epitomizes the spirit, inclusiveness, beauty, and positive message of 50 Shades of Black.  Claim this perk, show your support, and wear with pride!!! 

 

*BEAUTIFUL YOU Poster Signed by Ross Oscar Knight

Photographed by celebrated Atlanta photographer, Ross Oscar Knight, this beautiful poster features over 80 portraits and celebrates the beauty and the diversity of YOU!  Images captured during the 50 Shades of Black Inaugural Open Photo Shoot hosted by Ross Oscar Knight in Atlanta, GA!! 

 

When you Pre-Order our First Edition Book or Purchase our Custom Garment & Poster, You Are: 

EQUIPPING YOUTH, ENGAGING COMMUNITY, CHRONICLING HISTORY, AND EMPOWERING ARTISTS.  THANK YOU! 

 

YOUTH EDUCATIONAL CURRICULUM: 

With your financial contributions we will be able to develop educational curriculum complete with a supplementary booklet/manuel, facilitated workshop instructions, handouts, and exercises for teaching acceptance, tolerance, and understanding.  This cirriculum will be based on personal stories from around the world and artwork from 50 Shades of Black artists.  We seek to develop CONTEMPORARY approaches to teaching about diversity in K-12, college, the non-profit, corporate, and religious settings.

 

TRAVELING ART EXHIBIT:  

With your financial contributions we seek to create a traveling art exhibit highlighting the work of 50 Shades of Black Featured Artists and the stories their work illuminates.  While the traveling exhibit will be a permanent component of the project, we'd also make original works by the featured artists available for collectors.  This method serves to both spread the message of the campaign, educate audiences, and promote art collecting to new audiences.  

 

OPEN PHOTO SHOOTS: 

In an effort to provide people from all walks of life an opportunity to be professionally photographed and to continue to cultivate relationships with our partnering artists, we are committed to hosting 50 Shades of Black Free Open Photo Shoots all across the country.  Our goal is to offer everyday people a chance to see their natural selves in ways that many of them never have before.  It is also an opportunity to provide our partnering artists increased exposure and a way to be more actively engaged in their local communities.

SEE VIDEO & PHOTOS FROM OPEN SHOOT HERE
   

ORAL HISTORY PROJECT:

We seek to develop a traveling oral history booth for individuals, couples, families, friends to record stories about their experiences of race, skin tone, and/or sexuality in the formation of their identities.  Our goal is to build an archive of personal stories documenting American History for sharing, teaching, learning, and growing and to offer each participant a FREE copy of their audio recordings.

We are a collection of our stories...and we are writing new chapters every day.  No one can tell your story better than you. Releasing our stories is a powerful experience and can serve as a form of liberation for the storyteller and for other people who have had similar experiences.  That is the amazing thing about sharing stories...we soon realize we are not alone.

EMPOWERING and SUPPORTING LOCAL ARTISTS

We believe in the power of Art to change the world.  We also believe that the artists who create work that changes our lives should feel empowered and financially supported.  NONE OF THE ARTISTS WHO CONTRIBUTED TO 50 SHADES OF BLACK HAVE BEEN COMPENSATED.  They all contributed their work because they believe in the work that we are doing.  We feel it is our duty & our ethical obligation to provide them opportunities to advance their positive work through this project and with your help to offer them a financial support for their contributions.

Become Part of the Movement

We sincerely appreciate ALL of your financial contributions, but we realize that not everyone can give financially.  You can still join this movement, engage with its beautiful & critical art, and play a pivotal role in the succees of 50 Shades of Black.

*DOWNLOAD THE FREE EBOOK (iTunes or PDF)

*Share a Story with Us

*Share Your Art

*Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram

*Join Our Mailing List

*Tell a Friend

*Start Loving Yourself...TODAY

*DOWNLOAD THE FREE EBOOK (iTunes or PDF)

*Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
*Join Our Mailing List
*Tell a Friend
*Start Loving Yourself...TODAY

story:
Four year old raped. Finally, "the day came when the risk to remain tight in a bud was more painful than the risk it took to blossom." (Anaïs Nin). With my 4Spitfire to Blossom campaign, I am making this my moment to escape the silencing so common to this type of trauma; to use art, which is central to my own healing journey, to help other women, men, girls, and boys; and to give myself the chance to let my heart, mind, creativity, and soul blossom into a new place and space of healing, growth, and recovery from the tremendous wounding that occurred 44 years ago. Just typing the words “four year old raped,” I could feel my heart constricting, indeed tight, like a bud, and it brings tears to my eyes every time I hear how tiny my voice sounds in the YouTube video of my Phoenix poem (shared for the first time in 2009 at the 9Muses Creativity Café in Fort Lauderdale). Some of this feeling comes from the incomprehensibility of this occurring when I was only four years old, some from the incomprehensible facts that one in four women have been raped and one person is raped or sexually assaulted every four minutes (US DOJ).

Recovering from abuse feels as if I had open heart surgery, but nobody stitched up the wound, leaving it to fester and infect my life. I tried cowboy medicine and poured tons of alcohol on the wound, but it infected my ability to live my life in a way that wasn’t darkly colored by dis-order, dis-ease, disassociation, drunkenness, anger, self-abuse, and addiction. After the debilitating onset of post-traumatic stress disorder and flashbacks in 2000, I used in and outpatient treatment, support groups, and community resources (western medicine, alternative treatments, and anything else I could find) to conquer more than a dozen diagnosed dis-eases. During my journey, several therapeutic practitioners encouraged the use of journaling, creative writing, and collage; opening avenues for healing and blossoming in ways I had never fathomed. In the past four years I have explored the process of sharing, publishing, reading, and entering submissions into juried art shows; the baby steps that got me closer to today and choosing to use the unique platform offered by Indiegogo to end my silence.

With my tiny voice, with the tears I continue to shed, I intend to embrace my nickname, and to spit fire…using my words and art as a catalyst to move past the uncountable walls I have run into in the traditional/dominant health care and justice systems as I have tried to heal. After the disastrous toll PTSD took on my psychological and financial health, most recently I am running into walls while trying to move past the dependency upon the generosity of family with whom I have lived for a number of years. After a highly competitive process I was recently selected for a loft in an artist’s live/work coop studio, but I cannot get a traditional mortgage, probably for at least several more years of cleaning up my credit.

(1) My first goal, through this 4Spitfire campaign, is to purchase a live/work coop studio in which to create the art you are commissioning through your donations and selections of the “perks” I have listed. “A house is not a home unless it contains...fire for the mind as well as the body (Benjamin Franklin).” Playing with the idea of catalysts and spitting fire from hot peppers, all of the perks are designed to continue my process of using art to end the silencing of me and other girls, boys, women, and men who are raped, assaulted, or abused.

(2) My second goal is to launch this campaign today, four days before Valentine’s Day, also known as VDay, to raise awareness about this global movement to end violence against women and girls. http://www.vday.org/home

I am using this timing to spark and catalyze my art production to create an entry for an upcoming event called ArtPrize. http://www.artprize.org/

“Every fall, two thousand artists from around the world invade Grand Rapids, Michigan, to compete for half a million dollars in prizes. Their installations fill the city, from museums and galleries to restaurants, banks, and city parks. During the two and a half week exhibition, the public votes on the winner of a $200,000 prize, while world-renowned jurors select a $100,000 Juried Grand Prize winner, and five $20,000 winners based on categories. New for 2013, ArtPrize is partnering with The Walker in Minneapolis to help fund an ambitious project by a Minnesota artist for a prominent ArtPrize venue. Artists will create proposals for an installation on Gillett Bridge, a highly trafficked pedestrian bridge in the center of ArtPrize.”

I want to use my entry in ArtPrize to contribute to the idea of and movement toward creating a national memorial, one idea for which is being presented on the national mall on VDay: “'The most common trauma of women remains confined to the sphere of private life, without formal recognition or restitution from the community. There is no public monument for rape survivors (Judith Herman, Trauma and Recovery)'.” On VDay this February, FORCE: Upsetting Rape Culture is creating a public memorial for survivors and victims of sexual assault, sexual abuse and rape. During V-DAY’s 1 Billion Rising event, FORCE will float the words I can’t forget what happened but no one else remembers on the reflecting pool of the national mall. The statement, written by a survivor, reflects the isolating and traumatic experience of living with sexual violence. The temporary testament is a public call to create a permanent national monument to honor survivors.” http://onebillionrising.org/page/event/detail/startarising/4jvtb

(3) Because the internet has such power to surprise, if this campaign exceeds my fundraising goal, I will launch a second phase to raise funds under non-profit status to (a) bring additional therapeutic arts programming to the types of agencies that have been so helpful in my own healing journey and (b) continue raising funds toward a public memorial for survivors and victims of sexual assault, sexual abuse and rape.

Recall that one person is raped or sexually assaulted every four minutes. There are 525,949 minutes in a year, which means that 5,785,439 people were raped or sexually assaulted in the 44 years since I was abused.

Over the years I have given time and written grants and proposals that have raised hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands, and millions of dollars for other people, agencies, businesses, programs, and causes. I love that Indiegogo created this new crowd funding platform and hope that you can help me, help us, to end the silence. I am running this campaign for 44 days, to raise $44,444, hoping to provide some of services outlined in my “perks” starting in the fourth month of the year: April, which is Sexual Assault Awareness Month.

I know that some of you can’t contribute, but I would appreciate any help you could give to get the word out via Facebook, Twitter, your email list, any other creative ways you have at your disposal, or by using the Indiegogo share tools!

 

Savagely abused at age four

Severe shock stole my tears, voice, and soul

Thirty years passed

PTSD pressed upon my eyes

Pouring oceans of tears

Primordial ink, before speech evolved

Tears transformed from invisible ink

Stirred into my paint and pen

Shouting the reclamation of my soul

 

Information for Friends, Family & Partners of Rape & Sexual Abuse Survivors

http://pandorasproject.org/secondarysurvivors.html

During the two and a half week exhibition, the public votes on the winner of a $200,000 prize, while world-renowned jurors select a $100,000 Juried Grand Prize winner, and five $20,000 winners based on categories. New for 2013, ArtPrize is partnering with The Walker in Minneapolis to help fund an ambitious project by a Minnesota artist for a prominent ArtPrize venue. Artists will create proposals for an installation on Gillett Bridge, a highly trafficked pedestrian bridge in the center of ArtPrize.”
I want to use my entry in ArtPrize to contribute to the idea of and movement toward creating a national memorial, one idea for which is being presented on the national mall on VDay: “'The most common trauma of women remains confined to the sphere of private life, without formal recognition or restitution from the community. There is no public monument for rape survivors (Judith Herman, Trauma and Recovery)'.” On VDay this February, FORCE: Upsetting Rape Culture is creating a public memorial for survivors and victims of sexual assault, sexual abuse and rape. During V-DAY’s 1 Billion Rising event, FORCE will float the words I can’t forget what happened but no one else remembers on the reflecting pool of the national mall. The statement, written by a survivor, reflects the isolating and traumatic experience of living with sexual violence. The temporary testament is a public call to create a permanent national monument to honor survivors.” http://onebillionrising.org/page/event/detail/startarising/4jvtb
(3) Because the internet has such power to surprise, if this campaign exceeds my fundraising goal, I will launch a second phase to raise funds under non-profit status to (a) bring additional therapeutic arts programming to the types of agencies that have been so helpful in my own healing journey and (b) continue raising funds toward a public memorial for survivors and victims of sexual assault, sexual abuse and rape.
Recall that one person is raped or sexually assaulted every four minutes. There are 525,949 minutes in a year, which means that 5,785,439 people were raped or sexually assaulted in the 44 years since I was abused.
Over the years I have given time and written grants and proposals that have raised hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands, and millions of dollars for other people, agencies, businesses, programs, and causes. I love that Indiegogo created this new crowd funding platform and hope that you can help me, help us, to end the silence. I am running this campaign for 44 days, to raise $44,444, hoping to provide some of services outlined in my “perks” starting in the fourth month of the year: April, which is Sexual Assault Awareness Month.
I know that some of you can’t contribute, but I would appreciate any help you could give to get the word out via Facebook, Twitter, your email list, any other creative ways you have at your disposal, or by using the Indiegogo share tools!
 
Savagely abused at age four
Severe shock stole my tears, voice, and soul
Thirty years passed
PTSD pressed upon my eyes
Pouring oceans of tears
Primordial ink, before speech evolved
Tears transformed from invisible ink
Stirred into my paint and pen
Shouting the reclamation of my soul
 
Information for Friends, Family & Partners of Rape & Sexual Abuse Survivors
http://pandorasproject.org/secondarysurvivors.html

story:
ABOUT PASOS PEACE MUSEUM

The foundation has been laid for a dynamic, interactive, world class museum in New York City dedicated to peacebuilding, through education and the arts.  Pasos Peace Museum was established after 9/11 to connect, inspire and empower peacebuilders. Pasos does this through artistic exhibitions, community programs and our Virtual Museum.

 

PROJECT BACKGROUND

We seek your support for our two upcoming month-long exhibits that will be shown in New York City. 

  • "A Peace of My Mind" will open on February 22, 2013.  It is an award-winning collection of photographs and digital recordings derived from interviews of individuals with a wide range of backgrounds and experienes about their thoughts on peace.
  • "A Picture of Peace," an international photography exhibit showcasing photographs selected through a contest sponsored by the United Network of Young Peacebuilders, will open in June 2013.

 

WHY CHOOSE PASOS?

Pasos is a Spanish word meaning steps, crossing or passage.  We believe that Peace is achieved in steps and requires each of us to accept the challenge of reaching our full potential as peacebuilders.  We strive to connect peacebuilders around the world, stimulate their individual and collective imaginations, and take them to the next transformational steps leading to a just and peaceful world.

Pasos Peace Museum has been steadily growing since 2006.  Our most recent milestone was the receipt of a provisional charter as a museum from the State of New York.  We have made inroads, but we still have a long way to go toward achieving our vision of securing a permanent space and becoming the first fully chartered peace museum in New York City.  

Please join us on this exciting journey!  We invite you to visit our website, www.pasospeacemuseum.org, to learn more about the Museum and meet our people.

 

YOUR CONTRIBUTION

 Pasos's immediate goal is to raise $10,000 to cover the costs of the upcoming exhibits.  Your contributions will be used for:

  • Rental space
  • Shipping, insuring and mounting the exhibits
  • Artist compensation
  • Development of programs and curricula that will allow New York City school children to access and learn about the exhibits

The success of these exhibits will propel Pasos toward its goals of opening its first home and becoming a fully-charterd peace museum in New York.  Please help us make this happen!

THANK YOU!

In recognition of your generous donation, you will receive the following perks:

  • Any amount         

       A Pasos bookmarker 

  • $50.00                

       A Pasos t-shirt + Pasos Welcome Kit 

  • $125.00

A Pasos t-shirt + Pasos Welcome Kit + an autographed copy of "A Peace of My Mind"    

  • $250.00  

A Pasos t-shirt + Pasos Welcome Kit + an autographed copy of "A Peace of My Mind" + an autographed copy of “Museums for Peace: Transforming Cultures" 

  • $500.00   

        All of the above + Dinner with the Pasos Board and a surprise guest

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Visit our website at www.pasospeacemuseum.org, where you can tour the Virtual Museum, read our blog and sign up for our mailing list.

“Like” us on Facebook.

Share our Indiegogo campaing with your friends.

If you are an artist, submit your work for consideration in our Virtual Museum.  Visit our website for details.

Thank you for taking the time to learn about Pasos Peace Museum and our campaign!

story:
Greetings! Welcome to our BLIND WHINO: SW Arts Club x G40 Art Summit Indiegogo!

Our main objective in seeking your support flows through two main goals:

[GOAL #1] To raise funds for continued improvements to the 138 year old building nestled in Southwest Washington DC in our Nations Capitol. Although we have cleaned up the building and commissioned two amazing artists to paint the Exterior (HENSE - ATL) and Interior (MEGGS - AUS) of the building there is still quite a bit to do. We need to further improve the building with items such as painting on resin floors, bringing in 20 additional artists to paint the exhibit halls and project spaces, changing of light fixtures, repairing of the roof and items of the like.

[GOAL #2] Once our goal is met to solidify all cosmetics within the space we can initiate the second phase which is to raise funds for additional programing at our annual G40 Art Summit held in September 2013.  We are planning to do a full lineup of programming throughout the month to bring residents from DC, Maryland and Virginia down to the Southwest Waterfront. Programming will consist of Art Related Events, Musical Performances and Art Workshops. We are also planning a Private Fundraising Concert with special celebrity guests hosts and musical entertainment to help fund our project. 

BEFORE @ 700 Delaware Avenue Southwest Washington DC (2010)

The BLIND WHINO: SW Arts Club will inspire the community to spread the arts throughout Washington DC and will consist of Art related events such as art workshops, art exhibits and art events.

The building has remained vacant for two decades and will be coming back to life from the inside out with your support! 

Our gallery’s presence in the SW community initiated with the completion of the full mural wrap of the 700 Delaware Avenue building by Atlanta based artist HENSE. This project breathes new life into the neighborhood with a colorful and lively facade that enlivens the urban landscape.

AFTER @ 700 Delaware Avenue Southwest Washington DC (2012)

The success of this initial intervention was followed by the recently completed mural by Australian artist MEGGS. This second project brings life to the interior of the building with its graphic primary colors and colossal scale. Now that there is life both inside and out, the building will be a inspirational beacon for patrons within the DC region to come to the space and be overwhelmed with Art in a scale unlike anything seen before.

MEGGS Detailed Interior Mural @ 700 Delaware Ave (May 2013)

BLIND WHINO: SW Arts Club will house multiple project rooms for artists to do full scale art installations as well as ally the circulation spaces to house a massive group art show with the theme of "Transformation". The DJ Lounge area will be key for dedicated brand programming with large murals by world renewed muralists. The second floor will host the main performance area with a panoramic mural painted on the ceiling and walls of the space. This will be the feature platform for headlining entertainers to perform to up to 600 people.

1st Floor Layout @ BLIND WHINO: SW Arts Club
2nd Floor Layout @ BLIND WHINO: SW Arts Club

With over 15,000 square feet of potential art exhibits & entertainment, the images below showcases the BEFORE & AFTER  visuals. 

BEFORE @ 700 Delaware Avenue SW Washington DC (March 2013)
AFTER @ 700 Delaware Avenue SW Washington DC (May 2013)

It has been amazing to see the transformation of this beautiful building with new life brought on by these awe inspiring large scale artwork and with your help we can continue to transform this building to make it a gem in the Nations Capitol.  This will require a LARGE commitment of product and financial support, respectively. With the incentive packages to the right and samples of the rewards below, hopefully YOU are able to support US!

Perks:

Reward Print Samples (MEGGS, HENSE, Angry Woebots)

Blind Whino Schedule Specifics:

Location: 700 Delaware Ave SW, Washington, DC 20001

Located less than one mile from the US Capitol, within 4 blocks of 2 Metro Stations

Private VIP Fundraising Concert:  September 2013

G40 Art Summit Exhibition: Sept 13th - October 6th, 2013

Open Hours: Thursdays/Fridays: 7p – 11p  &  Saturdays: 12p – 11p

G40 2011 Recap:

Over 200 artists took over 25, 000 sq. ft (4 floors) in a transformed raw space tucked away on a heavily traveled 14th Street in the heart of the U Street Corridor. With 30 days of programming we housed live concerts, dance parties, celebrity panels and more. We even hosted a public daytime lounge with free Wi-Fi and endless free hydration of Vitamin Water, our G40 2011 corporate partner. Check out the Vitamin Water Uncapped Live Reel below for a full recap:

14th Street & Florida Avenue Northwest DC (G40 2011 Recap)
 
 

About G40 2013:

Art Whino will be teaming up with Suite Nation to present a month-long, multi- experiential Art Summit with extensive art programming and musical performances throughout the exhibition month.  This year’s theme is the “Art of Transformation” and the exploration of reclaimed spaces and objects. These will range from using found objects to create art installations, to transforming the space using artwork. The location of G40 Arts Summit this year will be an awe inspiring experience, as every inch is an all surrounding work of art. The building itself has a rich background. Completed by James A. Boyce over a 12-year period in 1875, it exhibits an eclectic Victorian style with Romanesque, Gothic Revival, and Queen Anne elements.

About ART WHINO:

Art Whino is a DC based art gallery whose mission is to bring together the pioneers and freshest talent from around the world. With over 1200 artists in the Art Whino arsenal, ranging from California to New York, Germany to Japan and beyond, Art Whino has become an all encompassing force in the art world. Exhibitions cover the whole spectrum of new art forms ranging from exposing emerging stencil and wheat pasting artists to showcasing the most skilled leaders of many different genres. http://artwhino.com/

About SUITE NATION:

The Sneaker Suite, originally launched in 2005 as a conceptual creative footwear showcase, served the community for over 8 years with custom branded events highlighting corporate sneaker entities such as Nike, Reebok Classics and more through high level productions such as Sneaker Pimps and Kicks for Kids Charity Shoe Drive. In 2008, the Sneaker Suite birthed a more focused category subsidiary entitled Suite Nation, a DC-based national event design firm serving clients outside the sneaker realm offering seamless one-of-a-kind opportunities for increased brand awareness and brand loyalty; providing a consistent, dedicated, influential audience for brand advertisers accordingly. http://suitenation.com

About HENSE:

Born and raised in Atlanta, Brewer has been painting for about twenty years. He developed much of his technique in the street as a prolific graffiti artist and later muralist, working under the moniker HENSE. Atlantans have long enjoyed his verve for capturing the energy of place in commissioned public art for the City of Atlanta on the Beltline, the Shops Around Lenox, and for the permanent collection of public art at the Atlanta Office of Cultural Affairs. Brewer has also painted in numerous U.S. cities outside of Atlanta and abroad in Spain, France, Japan, Taiwan and Mexico. His work has been exhibited in galleries in Atlanta, Los Angeles, Minneapolis, Miami, New York, Richmond, San Francisco, Tokyo, Taipei, and Barcelona. His client list also includes AOL, Adidas, Sprite, Hilton Hotels, TED, T-Mobile, Ford, and Kia. Brewer recently erected a large installation at the Museum of Design Atlanta and at the of July begins a large mural at the Virginia Museum of Contemporary Art. After a humble beginning roaming the roads with a spray paint can as a young man, his career has recently exploded like the pastel shapes and scribbles of his paintings. Selected exhibitions and projects include “Soft Light,” Sandler Hudson Gallery, Atlanta, GA, (2008); Mark Making in Black and White, Sandler Hudson Gallery, (2011); “Letters First,” Tokyo, Taipei and Barcelona, (2006); “Skate it or Hang it,” Museum of Design Atlanta, (2012); Public mural, Virginia Museum of Contemporary Art, Virginia Beach, VA, (2012); Float, Public mural, City of Atlanta Office of Cultural Affairs, (2011); Loose, Public mural, RVASAF, Richmond, VA, 2012.

About MEGGS:

Growing up in the Eastern suburbs of Melbourne, David 'Meggs' Hooke, immersed himself in the worlds of drawing, cartoons, sci-fi films and skateboarding. In 2000 Meggs graduated from University with a Bachelor of Design and soon after became recognized for stencils and poster art on the streets of Melbourne. In 2004 Meggs became a founding member of the renowned 'Everfresh Studio' a unique collective of street artists known for large amounts of collaborative street work and aerosol murals. In 2010 Meggs art directed and designed the 'Everfresh:Blackbook' a 254 page publication documenting the studio’s members, lifestyle and artworks from 2004-2010.The Everfresh Crew have more recently had collective artworks exhibited as part of 'Space Invaders' at the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra, as well as being the first artists to exhibit at the National Gallery of Victoria's (NGV) new NGVStudio space at Federation Square in Melbourne. Thus confirming this unique group’s status as historically documented pioneering artists within Australia's 'graffiti & street-art' culture.

story:
Short Summary

2 years ago this May 7th.  My wife came very close to dying during the birth of our son.  After just under a month in multiple hospitals she was able to come home to see our new family.  In speaking with her months later about the events, she mentioned that the biggest helper in her surviving something that should have killed her (Her liver ruptured) was all the people around us visiting, Calling, Texting, Sending Cards, etc.   She told me,  " I had no idea so many people loved me."

 I have always painted her something special for random occasions as a way to show her I love her in a unique way.  For the 2nd anniversary of my wife being given a second chance at life, as well as my sons 2nd birthday I want to do something AMAZING. 

 I plan to paint my wife something that can capture peoples love not just locally.  I will use this funding from people that understand the power love can bring and how amazing it is to paint her LIFE ANNIVERSARY painting.  This way every time she looks at it, she will be reminded that love is strong.

What We Need & What You Get

  • My goal is that I can finally upgrade from the warped slab canvas's I have been using.  To an actual deep stretched canvas.  I want this to be something in my family for generations. 
  • To upgrade to real paintbrushes.  I have been using old hand me downs and other random objects that seem to be able to hold paint.
  • I want to start using oil paints instead of acrylic.
  • I can't wait to take photos of the process to send to those who are able to support my cause.  To share with you all the unveiling of this "group" art masterpiece to my precious  wife
  • If I am unable to meet the entire goal that is ok.  A dollar helps me prove that Love is strong and the message will not be lost.  All the money I am able to raise goes purely into the purchase of supplies, which means I will be painting no matter what.  The goal of this is the message behind it.

The Impact

I hope that whether or not I reach my goal, everyone who does donate is a believer that love IS strong.  My wife and I are firmly believe that she would not have survived had she not actually been able to FEEL the love those around her have for her.

My hope would be that just by you visiting this campaign you will be reminded of the benefit we can have on those around us.  We all have people around us that although may not be in need of urgent medical attention.  They may still be able to benefit from feeling a little extra love today.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate and want to help: spread the word of my campaign on any of the many social media outlets.  And please feel free to spread the word even if you were able to donate ;)  

Thanks for taking the time to visit my campaign

My hope would be that just by you visiting this campaign you will be reminded of the benefit we can have on those around us.  We all have people around us that although may not be in need of urgent medical attention.  They may still be able to benefit from feeling a little extra love today.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate and want to help: spread the word of my campaign on any of the many social media outlets.  And please feel free to spread the word even if you were able to donate ;)  
Thanks for taking the time to visit my campaign

story:
Little update! My story and campaign have been featured on the MAJACRAFT blog! 

 

Short Summary

I am WoolWench. Friends know me as Suzy. I am a fiber artist and yarn spinner. I currently sell all the yarn I produce via my online Etsy shop, which can be found at: www.woolwench.com

I first started spinning when my daughter was a small baby, that was 17 years ago! Wow. And guess what, I am still using the same wonderful spinning wheel that I learned on. My goal now though, is to raise enough funds to purchase the fabulous Majacraft Aura Spinning Wheel (the ONE wheel to rule them all!), a wheel specifically designed to manage both traditional and mega art yarns! With it, I plan to take my creative art yarn spinning to the next level, while continuing to make wonderful functional yarn of great quality for knitters, crocheters, felters, and fiber artists all over the globe. Additionally, I would like to raise enough to make at least the minimum wholesale order of fibers, then I will be able to create even more wonderous yarns of all kinds as well as send you fabulous supporters the super perk skeins planned for you!

 

What We Need & What You Get

In a nutshell? Simple :) I need $1390 to purchase the Aura spinning Wheel.  To also allow me to straight away start with these extra special yarns I am planning to send to supporters, I also need to raise the $265 required to make a minimum wholesale order of fleece which I can then dye, and spin on the new wheel! Following the production of 'perk yarns' I will be working hard to increase my standard yarn range to include all sorts of wonderful fluffy and textured art yarns, which will be exhibited and sold through my online shop. I want to create this range as distinctive to me. I already have a strong branding for my yarns through the  unique and super high quality photos I make to showcase my yarn, however I want to now go a step further and start building a range of unique to me techniques, yet to be invented :) The Aura wheel will give me a lot more freedom to be inventive and follow my ideas to a final product on this ONE wheel!

If I am only able to raise partial funding, dont worry, if there is enough for the wheel only, I can still supply you with your wonderful yarns with retail sourced fiber! If I raise enough only for the wholesale fiber order, dont worry, I can still use my trusty old wheel to produce the reward yarns! So whatever happens, if you help out with at least $25+ you will get a beautiful yarn just as promised :) Please note, delivery outside of Europe takes an extra week or two from the estimated delivery dates listed with the perks!

UPDATE to perks! 

Here's a small addition to the 'Perks' available for supporters! I realise not everyone really wants yarn, so as an alternative, if you want to spin your own, or if you want to do something else like wet or needle felting, I also make drum carded fiber batts - So if you would prefer a batt as your perk, just leave me a note to tell me your preference and I will send you a batt instead! A $25 donate will get you one yummy batt and a $50 donate comes with two batts! And I might even throw in a little something extra as a surprise :) (for examples have a look in my Etsy shop www.woolwench.com -also in the 'sold' section)

And remember, I ship all perks worldwide at my cost! So even though you can certainly buy through my Etsy shop anytime, donating on my campaign is going to save you $$, and some of the yarns I am making are exclusive to this mission, so extra special :)

 

Heres the story of the One Wheel (in case you were wondering!)

In the dark time before handmade became known to all, before knitting and crochet was released from the drudgery of granny squares and itchy socks, the great wizard Majacraft created many spinning wheels with the power to create yarn, he released them into the world, where they were taken up by many, spreading the power of handmade far and wide. But he knew, they were lacking, their yarns were beautiful but missing the final creative force that would take yarn and its users to the next level. Humanity, and the fibers we used, started slipping back into the dark times, the hippies and earthchildren creating their earthforce yarns lost their souls and gave in to the mighty power of Massproducagon. These times were known only as 'the eighties' and they lasted several decades. But now, there is a new light in the world. The great wizard Majacraft could not let the world suffer under the constraints of yarns limited by orifice sizes and snaggy hooks, he joined forces with the incredible Pluckyfluff, legend among sheep and revolutionary bringer of a new age of yarnish enlightenment. Together they created The One Wheel, which they named 'Aura'. This wheel was destined to rule them all. Together, Majacraft and Pluckyfluff gave this wheel the power to take fibers and turn them into art, incorporating other objects of power into the yarn in a way never before seen.  With this wheel it became possible to spin amulets into the fibers, to create twists, knots, spin entire sheep into a creation of great wonder, a creation which would bring the dulled and uniformed humanity back to the art of needlecraft, wool art, natural fibers, and revitalise handmade, sending Massproducagon back into the crater of mediocrity.

WoolWench is part of this journey, striving to create inspirational yarns and artworks in fiber. She saw these wonderful creations that Pluckyfluff released into the world, and was inspired. She understood Majacraft, and felt drawn to the Aura, created in the very land where she was born and to which she was spiritually tied, and she instantly saw an expression of her potential in the spin of this wheel.  The Aura contains the power of her connection to the land and the forest, the spirit of Tane Mahuta, forest god, reflected in the rich colour of the Rimu wood used to give it form. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to support me on my spinning journey (and potentially save the world from one more polyester pantsuit) but you dont have the $$ to spare right now - its just as imporant and needed to spread the word and tell other people about me and my mission - share this page on your Facebook page, tweet about it, tell your neighbour, shout it in the cinema! Put a WoolWench Banner on your front fence! Stop people in the street and rave about my yarn! Well, you know I would be really really happy if you just share on Facebook ;P

story:
My goal for this fundraiser is to cover the cost for the custom framing, archival materials and promotional expenditures, associated with getting this series "exhibition ready." 

In completing my MFA thesis, I targeted the historical role of the LGBTQ experience through watercolor.  At times, in society, both the subject and the medium have been marginalized.  I held one motivating factor through this process: divergent communities can learn from each other through art exhibitions.

Although I come from a hub of awareness, this exhibit hopes to enlighten darker corners.  It is a series exploring the role of HIV, gender identity, persecution and liberation through the use of the parable.  Viewers are invited to a dialogue with the creative experience and with each other. 

You, as one of my global advocates, are invited to partner with me on this creative journey.  Perhaps you know someone coping with the AIDS pandemic or struggling to feel safe in a home because of whom he or she loves.  Perhaps you have overcome a chapter of history you now see repeating, or want to help write a new chapter.  Your support/donation to help this effort will be greatly appreciated.

story:
Short Summary

Marshall Edwards is a writer of speculative fiction, poetry, and independent comic books. He recently successfully funded and published his first superhero comic, Prairie City Response #1.  Marshall's MAYFLY is the story of a college professor who is reunited with an old friend - only to fall into the paranormal nightmare his friend's life has become.  Volume One, separated into six chapters, is nearly ready to print - all it needs are the terrifying illustrations of the talented Dennis Coyle III.

Dennis Coyle III is an illustrator working on comics for independent publishers. He recently worked on The Wisdom of Fools with 5th Dimension Comics and is providing work for Green Monkey Comics' Innocent Tales series.

Dennis is very excited about brining MAYFLY's shocking imagery to life.  This will be one of Dennis' first jobs as a full-time freelance illustrator.

Once funded, donors will receive a zine-sized booklet of Volume 1 on quality paper, containing an illustrated cover and an illustration per chapter.  If we reach $700, these copies will also contain concept art of the main three characters.

We have big plans for the future of this story.  with your help, we'll be off to a terrific start.  Thanks, and help us spread the word!

What We Need & What You Get

We are initially asking for $600 to cover the illustrations, printing, and promotional considerations.  If we reach $700, each printed copy will also contain concept art for the three main characters.  Funds beyond $700 will go towards coloring, art for future story arcs, and finalization of those story arcs. 

Donors of $5 or more will receive digital copies of MAYFLY Vol. 1 - five chapters of terror, comprising an introductory story arc, and brought to life by Dennis' illustrations.

Donors of $20 or more will receive signed printed copies on high quality paper: all the better to display Dennis' art!

Donors of $95 or more will receive original art from the MAYFLY series! We're talking a 11x17 art board of original art to creep out your guests and loved ones. 

If we do not meet the $600 mark, we may not have enough money to print the copies, though donors will still receive electronic copies.  Donors who qualify for original art will still receive the original art, but on a later time table.

The Impact

MAYFLY is Marshall Edwards' for foray into the horror genre.  A successfully funded and illustrated Issue 1 will be his ambassador to the world of horror, suspense, and science fiction.

Dennis Coyle III is a burgeoning, talented artist with an eye for the dark and disturbing.  By pooling our talents, we hope to make a unique mark on the world of horror.

This project will be successful - the story is finalized, and Dennis is prolific enough to turn this around in good time.  We plan to post a number of updates during the campaign itself!

Marshall's debut comic book, Prairie City Response #1, was funded last year and published this fall.  PCR #1 has pleased its readers with rock-solid writing and a unique art style.  The turn-around on this book should be much quicker - the end of January, let's say.

We aim to thrill you with captivating writing and artwork.  Given our track record, we won't disappoint!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, please help us spread the word on twitter, Facebook, and anywhere else you'd like! We're happy to answer questions about the comic and are available for interviews as well.  

We're easy to get a hold of on Twitter:

Marshall (writer): @prairiecitypost

Dennis (artist): @braindivide

Thank you!

story:
Lingua Parla is a website that allows you to learn to speak any language for FREE, by connecting you with native speakers.

 

 

Whether you're just starting out in your secondary language, almost fluent, but need more practice or you just need someone to talk to so you don't lose it, Lingua Parla is YOUR solution.

I’ve spent much of the last six years trying to find the best way to learn a new language. While there are many great ways of building vocabulary, memorizing conjugations and all-around filling your mind with useful information, absolutely nothing beats the experience and acquisition of knowledge that can be accomplished by speaking with a native speaker.

You'll be matched with the right people to advance your learning. In addition, you can search the chat rooms for someone to practice and strike up a conversation with (at their consent, of course).

Your payment to the other person is time: The person to whom you’re talking is also there to learn a secondary language (we matched them to you because you speak the language they want to learn). Each conversation will last 15 minutes, 30 minutes, an hour or whatever the two people agree upon. Half will be spent speaking in one language and the second half in another (a soft alarm will go off when it’s time to switch).

Lingua Parla will offer multiple facets. The main one will be video chat because it’s easier to understand people and learn given facial expressions and hand gestures. However, Lingua Parla will also offer voice and text chat for those without a webcam or suitable internet connection.

 
CONNECT WITH PEOPLE FROM ALL OVER THE WORLD! Do you like to travel? Not only will you learn a new language, but you'll be able to connect with people from every walk of life.

After registering, you'll simply fill out the information about what language you can speak and the language you want to learn or otherwise practice, and then you'll be matched to someone with whom you can practice.

Where your money will be going:
1. Paying our developers! We have two developers who will need to be paid to build this.
2. Paying our designer! Every great app needs an awesome GUI.
3. And of course, rewards for our donors.

The goals of this project include: Free language and cultural education for any willing participant, a coming together of many cultures, encouraging travel and world education of everyone; Plus many more!

If we get above the initial $2500, we have many long-term goals including mobile apps and basic lessons in every major language.

The Story (and why we're doin' it):

Federal, state and municipal budget cuts across the country have struck the most important parts of our infrastructure and our future - education. Public secondary schools as well as Universities all over the world are cutting back on etxra and co-curricular activities, but in an ever increasingly interconnected world, language programs (some of which are the first programs cut) are absolutely vital to our future.

Learning a secondary language with Lingua Parla will not only give you a better education for the future and make you more desirable on the job market, but it will give you a better fundmental understanding of the world. Lingua Parla won't just be another language learning program, but a community that brings culture and ideas together.

Lingua Parla, of course, is Italian for "The Tongue Speaks". Lingua itself is also understood as tongue by most people around the world and actually translates to tongue in four languages.

If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact me; I'm completely transparent. Here's my personal email address, it goes directly to my cell phone: c.ostmo@gmail.com

If you need any more information, visit the promo site we've set up: http://www.LinguaParla.com.

If you like this project, Please pass it on to others!

Also check out our new Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/LinguaParla

Ciao!

story:
Help us turn the electric on at our new space
we need a deposit of $2,000 in order to turn the power on
we also need money for supplies to soundproof the building

we are looking to open Mid Feb or March 1st 2013

the lease is signed, and a $8400 deposit has been put on the building

we are currently waiting for a hearing for a special permit(which cost almost $600) in order to have entertainment/shows

things are moving foward, they are just costing far more than I ever expected. 

if you are not familiar with the old AAR it was a local venue/store that in the 2 years it was open booked over 200 shows for bands from all over the world, big and small, and always helped touring bands

everyone from A loss for words, Junction 18, Colin of Arabia, boys like girls, the receiving end of sirens, four years strong, a loss for words, 100 demons, Dr. chud of the misfits, hawthorne heights played there, seriously lots of bands!

The new AAR will be an art space located in Downtown Taunton at 3 Trescott St.

things we have planned/are talking about so far:
all ages shows
art shows
an art gallery / lobby area
movie nights 
classes/workshops on everything from booking shows, band management to screen printing and drawing

story:
Why should I give?

Carl Heyward is a multi-disciplinary artist whose long involvemet in contemporary arts practice and community outreach is being rewarded by exhibition opportunities in Italy during the month of April 2013. Many aspects of his BUS PORTRAITS (photography) and MIXED-MEDIA work depict an observation and apprciation of  the universal need for privacy, of personal voice and the persistence of a transitional public identity in a containerized compressed culture.
 
Mixed Media works will be shown at Scaramuzza Arte Contemporane in Lecce, Italy from April 6th - April 27th 2013.
 
The Bus Portrait Series [Photographs] at Garage 21 in Ceglie Messapica, Italy from April 13th - April 27th, 2013.

Bio on Carl Heyward

Carl Heyward is an artist and writer living in San Francisco, California. He has exhibited his mixed-media paintings and artists' books internationally and has been collected by numerous institutions and individuals including: NY Museum of Modern Art Library, The Brooklyn Museum Clapp Library Special Collections, The Sackner Archives, Califia Books, The New Museum of Art (New York), San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, San Francisco Art Institute, San Francisco Academy of Art University, Yale University Art Library, The Australian National Gallery and Sonoma County Museum of Modern Art.

How can I help?

Support of the arts and artists in a direct, straight-forward way encourages the ongoing process and practice of contemporary practitioners such as Carl Heyward and others determined to pursue their calling by means of reciprocal promotion, sharing, questioning and support in an impactive and personal way.
 
Support directly via this link 
 
Support via PayPal (pending)
 
artspeak2020@yahoo.com
story_txt:
Why should I give?
Carl Heyward is a multi-disciplinary artist whose long involvemet in contemporary arts practice and community outreach is being rewarded by exhibition opportunities in Italy during the month of April 2013. Many aspects of his BUS PORTRAITS (photography) and MIXED-MEDIA work depict an observation and apprciation of  the universal need for privacy, of personal voice and the persistence of a transitional public identity in a containerized compressed culture.
 
Mixed Media works will be shown at Scaramuzza Arte Contemporane in Lecce, Italy from April 6th - April 27th 2013.
 
The Bus Portrait Series [Photographs] at Garage 21 in Ceglie Messapica, Italy from April 13th - April 27th, 2013.

story:
Hello world! My name is Nicole and I’m a senior design student at Pacific Lutheran University. I have a passion for making art, especially art that has that the power to make a positive impact in the world. One issue that has always been close to my heart is the injustice of human trafficking. For my senior project I’ll be exploring this social justice issue further by creating 3-D multi-media pieces paired with graphic prints. I hope to create pieces that provoke an intense emotional experience that becomes personal to viewers.

Funding

I want to make this project really awesome so it makes a lasting impression on viewers to the point where they are moved/inspired to do something to stop it. In order to make this project a reality I’m asking for funding in the amount of $2,750. This goes towards tools, materials, print services and other specialty craftsman services. If I don’t reach my goal all the funds will still go toward this but the piece itself won’t be as awesome as I originally envisioned.

The Impact

I don’t want to say that if you contribute to my campaign you’ll be stopping human trafficking. I do believe that knowledge is power and the fact that were saying it’s a problem hopefully will inspire more people to join the fight. This piece will be on display at Pacific Lutheran University so the minds of tomorrow and the public will interact with it. Personally, I’d like to imagine this project creating larger possibilities, like inspiring the next major human rights activist or connecting the right people at the right time to stop another human sale from occurring.   

Other Ways to Help

Any help is greatly appreciated. If you can’t help out financially just promoting this project (utilize the Indiegogo share tools) or the injustices of human trafficking in general is an enormous help!

Thanks for your time,

Nicole 

I can do things you cannot, you can do things I cannot; together we can do great things.           Mother Teresa

story:
About "Color Me Rad"

The idea is simple.  We want a coloring book that highlights the local justice work we support as a childcare collective, and embraces the values of love and liberation that inform our childcaring.  So we decided to make one!

  • The Chicago Childcare Collective is a group of volunteers who play with kids to support parent and caregivers' participation in racial and economic justice organizing in the city.

  • Coloring is such a calming, fun, important part of childcare.  We want to make the most of our time with kids by having coloring pages with extra special meaning.

  • We started dreaming about this project over a year ago, put out a call for submissions in November, and after tons of community input we're ready to print!

By contributing to our campaign, you'll have the chance to be a part of this community-driven project to bring stories of resistance and empowerment in Chicago to kids and people with crayons.  

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise funds for printing, and you need to make sure you can get a copy.  These are gonna go quick!

  • We're ordering 300 copies from Tampico Press in Pilsen for $575.  But since Indiegogo takes out some fees, and we need postage money for the perks, we're trying to raise $650!  

  • We want to save lots of copies to use freely with the kids and families we work with.

  • Give us $5-10 bucks and we'll give you a copy of the coloring book (pdf or printed!).  Donate more and we'll give you more books.  It's really exciting!

  • Once printed, we will be distributing books for a sliding scale rate, and a link to download the pages will be made available on our blog.

  • Any funds raised above printing costs will go to support kid and family participation at the 2014 Allied Media Conference!

You really want to be a part of this.  Really.

  • Over 35 artists submitted pages.  
  • 7 people translated the entire book so that it can be accessible in English and Spanish.  
  • An incredibly talented artist and designer edited the entire book and made our cover.  
  • An all volunteer editing team has been curating the book for months.  And some of the captions are real clever.
  • Several of our pages were already featured in the most recent issue of AREA Chicago: Childhoods, along with a story of how the coloring book came to be. 
This is your chance to play a part in making the dream of a Chicago-based radical coloring book a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to donate right now?  No worries!  There are still ways we can use your support!

  • Share this link on Facebook or twitter or tumblr or another one of those interwebs sites!  Help us make some noise!

  • Download the pages for free once we post it on our blog and use them whenever you have a hankering for coloring :)

  • Continue the essential work to make our activism, projects, events, and community organizing more accessible to kids, parents, caregivers and families by practicing community care together.

Thanks, friends.  <3 <3 <3

story:
Above - Dennis Ziemienski, Gunslinger, oil on canvas, 2014, 48x 36 in. Private Collection.

This October, the Old West and the New West will collide at the Tucson Museum of Art! A one-of-a-kind exhibition—Western Heroes of Pulp Fiction—will use art from comic books, pulp fiction novels, dime novels, and magazine and book illustrations to explore the ways in which mass media images of the Wild West have built and reinforced its status as the American land of legends. In fact, we dare say that this exhibition is the first of its kind in terms of media, scope, and focus. Interested? Here is the exciting part—YOU can be a lasting part of this historic exhibition by helping us get its catalogue published!

Comic Books? At an Art Museum?

That’s right! Popular art and mass media imagery are new frontiers in the field of the visual arts, as well as in Museum galleries. Scholars and the general public alike are beginning to pick up on the significance of casual art created for consumer use. Think about it—what better way to study the formation and function of mass ideas and beliefs of a given place, time, or culture than through the art that was produced for large-scale consumption and broad enjoyment by the public? What better way to understand how the American West became the Wild West we cherish than through the very images that formed and reinforced this world of tall tales and legends?

You know the wonder and imaginative awe these images provoke, as well as the deep nostalgia and meaning they hold. Maybe you grew up watching Rio Bravo with your grandfather during the holidays or played along with the Lone Ranger. Maybe you are a graphic designer with a love of classic Western illustrators which inspires you in your daily work. Maybe your Dad hums the tune of the Rawhide theme while he’s busy and quotes John Wayne when he’s feeling feisty. Or, maybe YOU have the greatest collection of Jonah Hex comics on the planet and attend every steampunk convention in America. If you fall into any of these categories, or any space in between, this exhibition and catalogue are for you!


Aaron Riley, Deadlands Gunslinger, Copyrights and Trademarks of Pinnacle Entertainment Group of Chandler, AZ.

How can I help?

One of the most important and lasting components of any great exhibition is its catalogue—a book that contains pictures of objects or reproductions of works of art in a show alongside essays, commentary, or scholarly critique. However, creating a quality catalogue that will last for years to come does not happen for free.  We need the help of our fellow comic and pulp fans, aficionados of old western film and television, Old West history buffs, and anyone else with a flair for cowboys and outlaws to make a donation in order to make this catalogue come to life. The book will be a hardcover with approximately 150 pages and over 65 color reproductions of art seen in the exhibition.

Why Do We Need a Catalogue Anyway?

The reason we are supposed to tell you:

 “This publication provides an additional resource of information about the exhibition, and provides opportunities for further scholarship and study of the subject beyond the gallery walls.”

The real reasons:

1.  A book like this has not been done before. Of course there were writers who have looked into pulp art, comic book art, and Western art before, but to put them all together in this kind of context is something new, unique, and in our humble opinion, pretty exciting!

2.  The catalogue lasts much longer than the exhibition itself. It is an item that can be taken home, read, studied, and remembered long after the art comes down from the walls. And, with our national catalogue exchange with museums, libraries, and schools across the country, it helps the exhibition reach anyone and everyone, from kids in rural libraries to scholars at world-famous institutions nationwide.

3.  Our fellow fans of this kind of art--those that go to ComicCon and PulpFest; those who know lines from Bonanza  by heart or own the collector’s edition of How the West Was Won on DVD; and those who cherish the work of classic illustrators--need this book. Period.

4.  Because it will be seriously awesome. That’s why. Just look at this cover!

RG Harris, Thrilling Western (Sheriff) “Gun Law,” 1935, oil on linen, 23 3/8 x 21 in. Private Collection.

All funds raised in this campaign will go directly to costs of publishing the catalogue, including reproduction rights, research, editing and layout, and physical production. Making our goal of $8,000 means that we will be able to produce an initial run of 1,000 copies in full Technicolor glory.  The catalogue is scheduled for print at the end of September 2015, in plenty of time for the exhibition’s opening on October 24.

What's In It For Me?

Well, at the very least, you get your name in a book! At any level of support, donors will receive acknowledgment on a special “thank you” page in the front of the catalogue. Think about it—remember that national catalogue exchange we talked about earlier? That means your name will be in a book that will be sent to places like the Smithsonian Institution, the Getty, and the Library of Congress. How’s that for bragging rights? No one else at the party will have that up their sleeve.

Depending on the donation amount, you’ll get plenty of other awesome perks too, like TMA membership, an invitation to the VIP exhibition opening in October, prints or collector’s pieces, Western Heroes of Pulp Fiction merchandise from the TMA store, your name on the donor wall of the exhibition and website, and maybe even a copy of the catalogue itself!

RG Harris, Wild West Weekly “Sonny Tabor’s Trail Drive,” October 18, 1935, print on paper, Private Collection

Who Are We?

This exhibition is curated by staff of the Tucson Museum of Art and Historic Block, Southern Arizona’s oldest and largest cultural organization. The Museum is dedicated to innovative promotion of art in all its forms, and accomplishes this through diverse exhibitions and education programs, serving as the steward of five of Tucson’s oldest historic properties, and acting as the most financially and culturally accessible arts and education institution in the region. To see more of the work we do in the community, and the fantastic exhibitions, programs, and events we host, check out our website at www.TucsonMuseumofArt.org

story:
Welcome to our Indiegogo page!!

Please also visit our blog (https://17turningpoint.wordpress.com/) where we will post updates on the work of each artist during this campaign.

We are 17 ceramics art students in our final year at Cardiff Metropolitan University and wish to raise money to fund our final Degree show taking place from 30 May to 6 June 2015 at the University and to take the show to Art in Clay show at Hatfield in from 3-5 July 2015 (http://www.artinclay.co.uk/).  

Turning Point consists of 17 ceramic artists, designers, potters etc producing work which expands, challenges and compliments ideas through experimentation in clay. Our degree show is set to celebrate the diversity that ceramics has to offer and the different professional pathways that they are graduating into.

So far we have raised 1,200 GBP through cake sales, cup sales, pot sales and various other events.  We still need to raise another 1,800 GBP to make sure we put on the best degree show Cardiff has ever seen, as this is the 150th anniversary of Cardiff Art School.  In fact we believe this is now the only pure Ceramics art course offered by any University in the UK.

We intend to use the money raised as follows:

Catalog about 1,800 GBP
Hosting the show about 500 GBP
Materials to exhibit the show about 300 GBP
Transport to Art in Clay about 300 GBP
Art in Clay show costs about 100 GBP

These are our best estimates based on the information we currently have available.

We should be very grateful if you could help us to achieve our goal and we have some very lovely rewards, which we hope you will find tempting.

We should also be grateful if you could tell all your friends and family about our campaign, even if you cannot contribute yourself.

Thank you in advance for your generosity, and we hope you can come and see us either at the degree show or Hatfield.
